course.dc:description: Contact us for more information.

This course is for anyone who has an interest in Engineering and is able to attend either full time or on a day release. For those having gained an apprenticeship who wish to study on a day release basis and for non apprentice students on a full time basis.
course.dc:subject: 2330 electrotechnical technology engineering lean eal soar
course.dc:title: Engineering Technology EMTA Diploma Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion of this course you can progress on to a level 3 qualification within a variety of engineering pathways.
course.mlo:objective:
The qualification focuses on practical skills and knowledge.  This ensures that when the learner completes the qualification they will have gained practical experience and a high expectation of some of the situations that they could face in a job role within the engineering sector.  This qualification has been designed to give a 'hands on' practical approach to engineering training.  It enhances foundation level knowledge supporting employer requirements.

You will cover six units of performing engineering operations supported by a technical certificate.

  1. Working safely in an engineering environment
  2. Carrying out engineering activities efficiently and effectively
  3. Using and communicating technical information
  4. Producing components using hand fitting techniques
  5. Preparing and using lathes for turning operations
  6. Producing plate work components and assemblies
course.mlo:prerequisite: For under 19s, a minimum of 4 GCSE passes at Grade D or above are required or Level 1 Engineering & Technology.  Mature applicants without formal qualifications but with experience in work-related areas are encouraged to apply.   All will be assessed at interview.

presentation.dc:title: Engineering Technology EMTA Diploma Level 2

course.dc:description: The course is part of the Progression Pathways offer at Cornwall College although it can also be studied outside of this package if preferred as a stand alone qualification.  This course is for anyone who wishes to improve their ICT skills.  Functional Skills ICT is offered from Entry Level through to Level 2.
course.dc:subject: vocation, hands-on, numeracy, literacy,
Information & Communication Technology
course.dc:title: ICT Functional Skills City & Guilds Level 2
course.mlo:objective: Functional skills ICT is designed to develop and assess functional ICT from entry level 1 to level 2 to ensure clear progression pathways and personal development opportunities. The qualification and assessment are intended to enhance skills application across a range of contexts. The knowledge, skills and problem-solving approaches contained within the qualification provide tools that can be utilised in work, life and further learning. This qualification will encourage learners to demonstrate their using ICT, finding and selecting information and developing, presenting and communicating information skills and are designed to develop and recognise the ability of learners to apply and transfer skills in ways that are appropriate to their situation. Functional skills are recognised as vital to learner’s personal development, increasing both confidence and effectiveness.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Ideally you will have an ICT qualification at Level 1 but an initial assessment will be carried out to esnsure you are placed on the most appropriate level.

presentation.dc:subject: Information & Communication Technology

course.dc:description: Three models required and a hairdressing kit.

You can choose from  Traditional Black & White Film or more current techniques for using Digital Cameras and software - we have the course for you!

 Dispense with digital. Find film. Adopt analogue. Learn the four principles of all image making.  Get right back to understanding how using basic techniques can improve your image making, all on  silver-based  photographic film and paper. Using black and white film, make your images, process your films and print onto photographic paper in an old-fashioned darkroom. Join us in a red-lit darkroom and have some old-fashioned fun.

Hours of fun with your camera.  Learn how to use Adobe's Photoshop program and techniques to create exciting texts, images and layouts.  Learn how to get the best out of your camera. Whether restoring old photographs or manipulating new ones, our Photoshop  course is the one  for you.

DIgital cameras are a modern way to capture precious moments and spectaular views, if you don't know how to get the best out of your digital camera then one of our workshops could be  the answer!

Basic practical theory of camera controls, film processing and darkroom work which underpins all creative picture taking

We also offer a range of courses related to Photography, both digital and traditional, please call 0845 22 32 567 for more details.
course.dc:subject: Digital camera photography pictures images photos darkroom processing photographs

course.dc:description:
Nancy Finch Reiki Stage 2 Tutor  Nancy joins our ACL team to deliver our Reiki Practioner programme.   She brings a wealth of experience, qualifications and knowledge to this area and has developed the Stage 2 course to include - ethics, professional boundaries and confidentiality, understanding symbols, practical treatments and attunements.   This course is suitable for those with a Stage / Level 1 and for those wishing to revisit their Reiki practice.

Disharmony almost always begins with a belief system. Patterns of self limiting beliefs - I am not good enough, I feel guilty, I am afraid to - from where negative emotions arise, can create an imbalance in the body. Reiki training will help you gently let go of these beliefs that serve no purpose to you, finding peace and healing in a safe environment.

Reiki is a very simple technique to master and is an energy technique where natural healing vibrations are transmitted through the hands of a Reiki practitioner (acting as a conduit) to the body of the recipient. The purpose of Reiki is to relieve stress and pain, induce relaxation, release emotional blockages, accelerate natural healing, balance energies and enhance peace.

Reiki is a simple yet profound system of hands on healing, developed in Japan that transcends cultural and religious boundaries.  It is also a gentle yet powerful path to personal and spiritual growth.  Reiki can have a profound effect on health and well being by rebalancing, cleansing and renewing your internal energy system.
course.dc:subject: holistic , complementary therapy , reiki , Reiki shares , healing , colour energy , Cornwall College St Austell

course.mlo:objective: Reiki is offered at Stages  1 and 2 currently and we now include Reiki shares for those who wish to benefit from  exchanging  healing energy in a group environment .

course.dc:description: The course will appeal to students who want to communicate their ideas visually, are interested in the relationship between art and photography, enjoy looking at and discussing photographic work and want to engage with practical project-based photography.

There will be five hours per week supervised tuition. At A-level you are expected to take responsibility for your own learning and to work in your own time with the support and advice of your lecturers. You will need to undertake much of the practical work involved in your own time, particularly at weekends.
You will be expected to prepare for lessons by reading and, usually, making your own notes and you will be required to research the work of historical and contemporary photographers and develop an understanding and appreciation of their working methods.
course.dc:title: Art AQA GCE A2-level (Photography)
course.learningOutcome:
At the end of the course you should have developed a strong ability to communicate your ideas through the medium and have developed a sense of visual literacy that allows you to appreciate the language of photography, painting and film.

Entry to Higher Education photographic courses is contingent on a strong portfolio of work and this course will provide you with the opportunity to develop a portfolio for application to HE institutions.

Many students see photography as a unique bridge between art and science and combine it with other courses to add breadth to their education. Photography also works well in conjunction with art or media based programmes.
course.mlo:objective:
The majority of the course is based on the practical production of your own photographs. The programme is divided into four modules:

  • The Studio; in which students are taught about studio lighting and techniques.
  •  The Street; in which students complete a documentary assignment.
  •  The Land; in which students respond to ideas and approaches toward photographing the landscape.

The fourth module is concerned with responding to the examination question paper. You will also be given contextual studies′ lectures which explore the work of a number of significant historical and contemporary photographers and the ideas and techniques behind their work.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Five GCSE grades at C or above, plus the successful completion of AS level to grade C in this subject. 

It is sometimes possible for mature students to do A level Photography in one year by taking the AS level and A2 course concurrently. This is largely dependent upon experience and ability.

course.dc:description:
This course is for those who have had difficulty settling into their chosen study programme, who may need further support with Functional Skills, or who have experienced personal issues that have preventing them from achieving  their goal.

City & Guilds' Employability and Personal Development qualifications help you to demonstrate that you have the personal skills, qualities and attitudes needed by employers. They will help you to look for, obtain and maintain employment. By developing your skills and confidence, these qualifications may also help you progress into further education and learning.
course.dc:subject: Preparation for Life & Work
course.dc:title: Way Finder Programme
course.abstract: This course is for those who have had difficulty settling into their chosen study programme
course.learningOutcome: You can apply for other FE programmes of study or gain employment.
course.mlo:objective:
Depending on your start date during the academic year learners will work towards some of the following:

 

  • Level 2 Award in Employability and personal development
  • Level 2 Certificate in Employability and personal development
  • Level 1 BTEC in Home cooking skills
  • Level 2 Award in Barista Skills
  • Function Skills in English and Maths (if required)

 

There are also opportunities to try out other vocational subjects, for example:

  • Photography
  • Catering
  • Art
  • Music
  • Motor vehicle
course.mlo:prerequisite: Ability to work at level 1 or above.  An interview will identify suitability for each applicant.

Apprenticeships
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Culinary Chef CG Diploma Level 2
course.abstract: This is an ideal course for those looking for a first step into the Hotel and Catering industry
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion of this course, you can enter employment as a Chef or you can continue onto a Level 3 programme at the college.
course.mlo:objective: You will learn the Principles of food preparation and cooking, become skilled in such important skills as frying, baking, grilling, poaching, steaming and griddling and you will learn how to prepare and cook a variety of interesting and exciting dishes including meats, fish, sauces, soups, vegetables, salads, pastries, and hot and cold desserts. You will also undertake Functional skills, ERR, CIEH food safety award, Sustainability in Professional Kitchens, Introduction into foraging and wild food, Allergen awareness, safety and hygiene in the kitchen and the importance of teamwork in cooking for our busy restaurant.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements although you will need to show a strong commitment to pursuing a career in food preparation and cookery and have literacy and numeracy skills to Level 1 or above. All applicants for will be required to attend an interview and assessment.  If you are at all unsure as to your suitability for the course we will discuss each individual at an arranged interview. Please contact the college and the programme manager will be happy to discuss the course and its content with you.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you wish to develop your practical skills and learn contemporary techniques in the production of fermented dough products, petit fours, paste products, desserts, chocolate and sugar work.

You'll need: a level 2 qualification in Professional Cookery or equivalent, or expeience in the catering industry.

You'll learn: from a combination of practical and theoretical units which will be delivered inan excellent industry-level environment. In addition to developing practical skills and contemporary techniques in patisserie and confectionery, you will also study the nutritional values of foods and ingredients, management and supervisory skills, successful kitchen management and how to store, prepare and cook food safely.

Expect: to be assessed throughout your course through assignments, projects and practical examinations.

You'll love: that whatever your passion, or specialism, we will help hone your talents and bring out the gastronomist in you, with a number of culinary and food foraging trips, restaurant visits and the organisation of a Gastronomy Fair.

You'll go onto: employment or university study such as our Foundation Degree in Hospitality and Tourism.
course.dc:subject: Cookery Patisserie Confectionery Food Professional Diploma Catering Chef Cooking Cake Pastry Chocolate
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Patisserie and Bakery Skills CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Develop your practical skills in a variety of techniques associated with desserts, chocolate and sugar work
course.mlo:assessment: You will be assessed throughout your course through assignments, projects and practical examinations.
course.learningOutcome: After successfully completing the NVQ 3 and with sufficient industry experience you will have the opportunity to progress onto a Foundation Degree. This qualification will also enable you to apply for positions in first class establishments with the knowledge that the qualification will enhance your job prospects.
course.mlo:objective:
You will be attending the college for one day a week, developing the advanced techniques for working nationally and internationally in Patisserie and Confectionery.  You will be training in fully equipped, industry standard kitchens, gaining further experience servicing our silver service restaurants and learning in a highly innovative environment where creativity and enthusiasm is actively encouraged.

Areas of study will include:

  • Bread and Dough Products. From sour dough to focaccia, to doughnuts and lardy cake.
  • Cakes, Sponges, Biscuits and Scones. This will include Christmas cakes, brandy snaps, yule logs, macaroons and many types of cakes and gateaux.
  • Sweet and Savoury Pastry Products such as strudels and suet puddings.
  • Chocolate Products. This will include truffles, marshmallows, moulding chocolate in all sorts of shapes as well as making chocolate flowers and figures. 
  • Marzipan, pastillage and sugar products. Not only will you be modelling and moulding using many types of mediums such as icing, sugar paste, boiled sugar, fondant and more, you will also be using a variety of skills such as casting, moulding, piping and dipping.
  • Hot Deserts, steamed sponges, various apple dishes, soufflés, classics puddings and the rich sauces to match.
  • Cold Deserts, cheesecakes and mousses, charlottes and jellies, sorbets, ice creams, parfaits, frozen soufflés and much more.
  • Sauces, fillings and coatings. Creams, fillings, sauces, glazes, sabayons, meringues.
  • Functional skills
  • ERR
  • CIEH level 3 food safety award
  • Sustainability in Professional Kitchens level 3
  • Food science
  • Product development and food costing
  • Allergen training
  • Artisan bakery workshop
  • Chocolate from bean to bar

The list covers a multitude of all sorts of confections to raise your skill level.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements. However, because of the advanced nature of the course it is advisable that you are either the holder of NVQ level-2 Food Preparation and Production or City and Guilds 706/1 and 706/2 or are already working in a first class establishment. Equally, you can be a mature student who may never have attended college and would like to gain a nationally recognised qualification. In all cases real enthusiasm for the industry and a love of food is vital.

course.dc:description:
All students are encouraged to bring male clients to the course. We would also recommend that you purchase a male block as some work can also be achieved on this. Cornwall College could help you with this additional cost. For further information, please follow the link:

Learner Support Bursary Fund

This course is offered as a separate qualification for both qualified hairdressers and those working towards a hairdressing qualification.

This is also offered as an additionality if you are studying a full time Level 2 or level 3 programme within the hairdressing department.

Men's hairdressing and barbering is a specialist skill and is currently in demand with the growth of the men's hairdressing and barbering industry. The Men's City and Guilds cutting award is taught by an experienced barbering specialist and includes theory work, demonstrations and hands-on workshops. Endorsed by Habia, this qualification is a useful addition to your training and could help you progress in your current employment. You may also run your own salon and wish to offer Men's styling and barbering as an additional service.
course.dc:subject: Barbering Hairdressing Hair Men Mens Beauty
Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Cutting Men's Hair CG Award Level 2
course.abstract: Mens hairdressing and barbering is a specialist skill and currently in demand
course.learningOutcome:
You could continue your studies with Cornwall College by upgrading to a level 3 and 4 qualification in Hair or add extra units to the Barbering qualification. Cornwall College offer pathways in Hair, Beauty and Holistics and you could diversify by studying additional qualifications.

The level 2 in Barbering is an excellent route if you are looking for employment and a career in gents cutting and grooming techniques.
course.mlo:objective:
You will train in our professionally run salon under supervision of our barbering expert who will guide you through layering, club cutting, the scissor over comb method, use of clippers and free-hand cutting techniques.

You will also acquire the knowledge necessary to undertake different styles, recognise different hair types, groom men's facial hair, work with natural hairlines and baldness and consult with clients on after care.

All workshops are hands-on. You will be given demonstrations and lectures in support of your practical training and theory is assessed by online multiple choice tests.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Typical applicants for this course are qualified hairdressers or working towards a level 2 or 3 hairdressing qualification. You may also be looking to refresh your knowledge in Barbering.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you want to work in the masonry area of construction

You'll need: to attend an informal interview to discuss your suitability for the course

You'll learn: through theory sessions and practical training covering essential industry areas such as health and safety, erecting masonry structures, efficient work practices, and moving resources

Expect: to be assessed throughout your course

You'll love: the industry focus of this course, equipping you for a successful career in construction

You'll go onto: employment, an apprenticeship or further studies at level 3 on our Trowel Occupations (Construction) Diploma

 

This course is aimed at people who wish to gain qualifications in the masonry area of construction.  Qualifications are gained through assessment of competance in the workplace. 

This course can be studied either as part of an apprenticeship where you will be in the work place and attend college one or two days per week, or through  OSAT (on site assessment training), for experienced construction workers who will gain the qualification whilst in the workplace by an assessor collecting evidence of competence.

course.dc:description:
Some of the units covered include:*

Studio Recording and Engineering – This unit aims to enable learners to develop theoretical and practical knowledge of studio recording, including factors affecting audio quality, equipment and effective planning of recording sessions.

Computer Music Composition and Production - The aim of this unit is to enable learners to use the music composition, production and audio features made available by modern computers.

Music Composition Techniques - The aim of this unit is to enable learners to use different composition techniques to produce coherent musical compositions.

Applied Music Production Techniques - The aim is to enable learners to research and recreate accepted and innovative studio production techniques before developing a personal approach to music production.

Audio Mastering and Manufacture - The aim of this unit is to enable learners to apply audio mastering skills by preparing recordings for the manufacturing process.

Planning for Public Performance - Planning and running a public event. The aim of this unit is to enable learners to develop the skills required to research, plan and manage productions for public music performance.

*subject to approval

HNC DJ & Electronic Music Production
UCAS Code: 383W
Institution Code: CORN C78

HND DJ & Electronic Music Production
UCAS Code: 38HW
Institution Code: CORN C78

Future music industry professionals will require a range of essential creative and personal skills to be successful. Relentless ambition, drive, strong communication skills, entrepreneurial vision coupled with raw talent makes the developing music professional a formidable prospect. As with all dBs Music courses we help you identify and develop these essential ingredients so that you can achieve your goals. So if you're looking to become a cutting-edge electronic music maker or DJ who's not only looking to write and produce music to a releasable standard, but also to push the boundaries of modern electronic music production and performance then this is the course for you.

Modules

Year 1 modules make up the HNC Year 1 and 2 Modules make up the HND.

 Year 1 HNC

  • Aural Perception & the Principles of Musical Sound (20 credits)
  • Research & Analysis of Musical Genre (20 credits)
  • Electronic Music Events Management (20 credits)
  • Electronic Music Composition Techniques (20 credits)
  • Studio Recording & Engineering (20 credits)
  • Audio Mastering (20 credits)

Year 2 HND 

  • Critical Music Listening (20 credits)
  • Work Related Experience Interacting with the Music Industry (20 credits)
  • Major Project (20 credits)
  • Advanced Synthesis & Sampling Techniques (20 credits)
  • Sound System Specification & Operation (20 credits)
  • Live Electronic Music Performance (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: music, music performance, recording, sound, performing, singer, musician, music industry, composer, song writer, song writing, raping, dj, djing, playing, instruments
Arts, Media & Performing Arts
course.dc:title: HND DJ and Electronic Music Production
course.abstract: Push the boundaries of modern electronic music production and performance.
course.learningOutcome:
Potentially you can apply to progress on to the second or final year of a number of full degree programmes following successful completion of the HND but this may be at the second year stage or third year. Decisions will be made on an individual basis by application.

  • BA (Hons) Live Music final year with dBs Music at University College Plymouth Marjon
  • BA (Hons) Music: Technology final year at Plymouth University
  • BA (Hons) Music: Composition final year at Plymouth University 

Our Careers Service is available to give information, advice and guidance on all aspects of education, training and career progression. Tel: 01209 616270 Monday, Tuesday and Thursday (9am- 4pm) Email: careers@cornwall.ac.uk
course.mlo:objective:
From the outset, through formal lectures, practical workshops and assignments, you will be encouraged to combine these skills to create quality, contemporary electronic music. Upon completion of the course you will be well on the way to building a career as an electronic music producer and performer.

Over the two years you will cover a range of practical and theoretical subjects such as composition, sequencing, synthesis, sound design, audio editing, mixing and mastering, live sound and performance techniques using a range of traditional DJ and software-based platforms.

In addition to covering essential composition and production techniques, you will explore new and exciting methods of sound creation and manipulation using Native Instruments Reaktor software to develop your own performance tools, synthesizers and signal processors. The course will allow you to study this area in greater depth, mastering your craft and looking at new ways of delivering your music, incorporating the latest computer-based performance technologies.

Alongside the technical and creative work you will be developing your personal and business skills which include, event management, online business, budgeting and finance, management, career strategy, project management, PR and marketing and event management.

This brand new course is taught at dBs Music's premier training centre in Camborne, Cornwall (http://dbsmusic.co.uk/cornwall/). As with all dBs Music centres, students will find industry experienced staff, excellent equipment and a relaxed learning environment.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

We interview all applicants, part of your interview will be by audition to demonstrate performance skills or your demo/show reel of examples of work: the standard of your portfolio of work, coupled with your experience, enthusiasm and commitment is given consideration.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

course.dc:description:
BSc (Hons) Horticulture (Garden and Landscape Design)

Institution code: DUCHY D55

UCAS code: 4RL6

Campus: The Eden Project (subject to Plymouth University site approval)

Entry requirements: 240 UCAS points from AS & A-levels or relevant level 3 qualifications. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and maths.

Duration:  3 years full time, 6 years part time

 

BSc (Hons) Horticulture (Garden and Landscape Design) has been specifically developed to provide industry focussed design capabilities and general high level horticultural knowledge that is applicable all sectors of the UK horticultural industry. The programme of study and student experience are greatly enhanced through the collaboration between Duchy College and the Eden Project. The mixture of resources including Eden's plant collections, growing environments, nursery and new dedicated teaching facilities coupled with the nationally renowned micro-propagation research facility of Duchy College Rosewarne, provide a world class platform from which this exciting and stimulating programme will be delivered.

Learners embarking on this programme will become integrated within Eden Project and, in addition to attending the carefully designed taught modules, will have the opportunity to apply and develop a wide range of practical skills by participating in activities in the tropical and Mediterranean biomes, the outdoor garden and nursery crop production facility. As well as benefiting from working alongside Eden's skilled and specialist horticulturalists learners also undertake a work placement within another commercial enterprise.

The Personal & Employability Skills Development module will help you to develop the skills you will need to find and sustain a career when you graduate. The module will also enable you to develop a pattern of reflective practice that will aid you in your search for a successful career.
course.dc:subject: Horticulture
course.dc:title: BSc (Hons) Horticulture (Garden and Landscape Design)
course.abstract: This programme develops industry focussed design capabilities and general high level horticultural knowledge.
course.mlo:assessment: Assessment is by a mix of examination and coursework, including public presentations at student delivered symposium and poster presentation of design research findings.
course.learningOutcome:
Possible Further Study (subject to availability)

  •  MA in Garden and Landscape Design (various institutions)

Possible Careers

  • Garden Designer
  • Landscape Designer
  • Landscape
  • Planning adviser
  • Municipal parks and gardens manager
  • Estate garden manager
  • Horticultural retail manager
  • Nursery stock producer
  • Specialist propagator
  • Garden historian
course.mlo:objective:
The programme of study is delivered through a mix of lectures, seminars tutorials, laboratory sessions and practical hands on experience and skill development delivered across the facilities at Eden. Learners undertake a piece of novel design research work in the final year to explore industry focussed design issues. Assessment is by a mix of examination and coursework, including public presentations at student delivered symposium and poster presentation of design research findings.

This variety of practical opportunity, scientific exploration and new facilities provide an intellectually stimulating academic environment which introduces learners to new concepts, ideas and opportunities and provides a base from which to build an exciting and rewarding career in horticulture.

The Personal & Employability Skills Development module will help you to develop the skills you will need to find and sustain a career when you graduate. The module will also enable you to develop a pattern of reflective practice that will aid you in your search for a successful career.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
240 UCAS points from AS & A-levels or relevant level 3 qualifications. Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and maths.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply (GCSE English and Maths at grade C or above- or equivalent qualification- are required).

All applicants are invited to attend an interview as part of the application process.

If you are unsure of your suitability please call us on 0845 60 50 455 or email enquiries@duchy.ac.uk.

course.learningOutcome: There are several flexible progression opportunities for delegates onto other degree level short courses, including: Web design and authoring; Effective marketing and many more. Training at all levels and in a range of subjects is available through Cornwall College Business.
course.mlo:objective:
You will develop practical techniques including combining type, symbols and images. You will also explore advertising, branding, editorial and typographic methods to create imagery ready for print or web media.

The course covers;

  • The practice and theory of the design process
  • Understanding theories of composition, legibility, colour, influences of society, gender and class
  • Developing practical image making methods and techniques
  • Developing your skills using Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Illustrator
  • Project planning
  • Evaluation

The course will be delivered through practical sessions. Delegates will have access to online support materials and a designated tutor for learning support. Delegates will have to undertake an assignment to successfully pass this course.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements for this course.

The course will be delivered through practical sessions. Delegates will have access , to online support materials, and a designated tutor for learning support. Delegates will have to undertake an assignment to successfully pass this course.

If you have little knowledge of websites and you would like to take control of your web presence then the How to Sell Online course is for you.

This course will help you to:

  • Gain an overview of what you need to know about running a website of your own
  • Create a professional quality website that you can manage and update yourself
  • Free yourself from dependence on your web designer/developer
  • Manage your site from any device with an Internet connection any time anywhere
  • Develop a web design solution that won’t lock you into anything or anyone
  • Get a SEO friendly website drive more traffic to your site
  • Sell products and services simply and effectively - you are in control

course.learningOutcome: There are several opportunities for progression onto other performance boosting short courses for business, including Web Design & Authoring, Server Side Programming (PHP), Enhance your E-marketing, Effective Marketing and many more. Training at all levels and in a range of subjects is available through Cornwall College Business.
course.mlo:objective:
At the end of this course you will be able to:

  • Use the Internet as a research tool in relation to web applications
  • Have a basic understanding of web scripting languages (HTML and CSS)
  • Register domain names and install a WordPress content management systems (CMS) via a control panel
  • Install and customise a CMS theme and create and upload bespoke content
  • Customise a CMS using an online editor
  • Install, configure and maintain an ecommerce module
  • Have a basic understanding of ecommerce,  web marketing and search engine optimisation

The course is delivered through lectures, practical workshops and on-line learning. Successful completion of this course will require the delegate to show an understanding of e-commerce concepts, systems development tools and techniques to produce a database driven website.

This course is for anyone who would like to progress their web development skills specifically to provide media rich content and enhanced interactivity to their websites. It is ideal for individuals or businesses who wish to enhance their web presence, using industry standard hardware and software (Adobe CS5).

Multimedia Web Design and Authoring provides an ideal follow up to Introduction to Web Design and Web Design and Authoring. It is highly recommended that at least one of these courses should be attended before attempting Multimedia Web Design and Authoring, especially if you have no prior experience of Adobe software or web design.

course.dc:description:
Want to work in Television, Film, Journalism, Advertising, Radio, Web Design, Game Design or Animation? Then this is the course for you! Not only do you develop practical, technical and theoretical knowledge, but also the bonus is that it is a coursework-based course, meaning no exams!

An Extended Diploma is the equivalent of 3 A-Levels. This course will particularly appeal to those learners who have an interest in studying media in a way that may be reflected within their own lives and experiences.Alongside this course you will study two additional courses. In year one you will undertake a BTEC National Award in Photography and during year two you will undertake a BTEC Certificate in Web Design, Animation and Game Design all of which carry valuable UCAS points, ensuring you get the university place you want, whilst also enhancing your CV with valuable credentials.

The Extended Diploma Media Production course is a full time programme which means you will be in college from 9.00am - 4.30pm four days a week. Learners have one study day where essential equipment is readily available for your use. Every Wednesday afternoon free time is given for enrichment activities. This is a great place to meet people and make friends. Clubs include - Film Club, Drama Club, Student Newspaper, Duke of Edinburgh Award, Driving Lessons, Skateboarding, Cookery, Gym, Swimming, Surfing, Computer Games Club, Paintballing and more.
course.dc:subject: media T.V Film animation Television production Journalism Advertising Radio Web Design Animation, multimedia, editor, writer, journalist, film maker, cameraman, film school
Arts, Media & Performing Arts
course.dc:title: Creative Media Production EDEXCEL BTEC 90-Credit Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Want to work in Television, Film, Journalism, Advertising, Radio, Web Design, or Animation? Then this media course is for you!
course.learningOutcome:
Successful completion of this course will widen your future career prospects and employment opportunities within the media industry. Past students have gone on to work in TV production and presenting, advertising and marketing, journalism, film production, radio production, public relations and multi-media web design.

The broad and inclusive nature of the Extended Diploma Media Production course has also seen past students move into careers in teaching, counselling and business driven sectors such as commercial advertising sales. There is also the prospect of progressing onto one of many Higher Education courses either here at Cornwall College or further a-field whether it be at Degree or Foundation Degree level.

Former Cornwall College Camborne Extended Diploma Media student views:
"The ED Media course in my view was the best way to prepare for a career in the media, it gave me the knowledge, confidence and ambition to break into one of the most challenging industries around"

Dan Warren (Senior Producer - ITV1), Producer Credits include ITV1, Optimistic Entertainment, Endemol UK, FIVE, Flextech and ITV2
"I really enjoyed studying the BTEC Media Production course, and in particular the variety of disciplines that were touched upon and the practical nature of each"

Daniel Norris (Producer - American Idol currently living in LA), credits include ITV1 Ant & Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway, SKY1 Brainiac Science Abuse, ITV1 X Factor, ITV1 Britain's Got Talent
"Being a student on the ED Media course at Cornwall College Camborne has without doubt been the best two years of my life. Great tutors, great friends, great times.", Scott Hayley, Now studying Radio Production and Sport Development Ba at the University of Chester
course.mlo:objective:
The Extended Diploma in Media Production offers study in; camera work, digital video and photographic editing, Photography, Adobe Photoshop, scriptwriting, production management, film analysis, animation, web design, music video production, 3D design, After Effects, commercial production, journalism and lots more including our two week intensive nationally recognised film making machine, Film School.

The additional qualifications you will undertake in Photography, Animation, Web Design and Game Design will enhance and expand the platform of skills that you will take into your first job, or university degree. Study in these additional courses will include; producing websites, digital advertisements, special effects, photographic darkroom skills and more.

As media professionals themselves, the course team structure the programme around their learner's interests allowing students to simultaneously look at the larger industry whilst working towards specialising in areas and roles that interest them. This ethos culminates in a Final Major Project in the second year in which the student will create their own media product supported by the course team. Past projects have included short films, television shows, documentaries, photographic exhibitions, fashion and lifestyle magazines, computer games and social action media.

Past students have worked on a variety of video, audio and print projects for real clients including the National Animal Welfare Trust, the NHS, Cornwall and Devon Fire Service, National Stop Smoking service and live broadcast of the Cornish Pirates rugby games and British Professional Surfing Tour to name a few. Professional projects completed on the course have received much acclaim in the local and national press and the College's efforts to give students professional experience have achieved a Beacon 'Highly Commended' Award for the centre in 2008.

In addition, students will have access to a wide range of professional equipment, effectively allowing them to focus on their own personal projects and videos whether it is skate videos, zombie films, review blogs or comedy pieces. The kit includes HD Canon 5 & 6 D cameras, four camera television studio, recording studio,  Green-screen facilities, steadicam rigs and mounts, 12ft extendable camera crane, portable LED lighting kits, broadcast quality cameras,  and a bank of water cameras including the new HD Go Pro Hero 3, all of which is available to our students to hire at no cost!

However, that's not all. The media course pushes students to work in professional environments with working practitioners. During year one, students will embark on a two week intensive film school project hosted by Dogbite film crew at their incredible film studio in Falmouth. Students will create, shoot, edit, pitch and present a complete film product to industry professionals who have included past Oscar Winner Jane Pugh and Ant and Dec's Creative Director Mike Cunliffe alongside Film Armourer Dan Johnson, who has worked with Steven Spielberg and Matt Damon. The second year will see the student group work alongside Journalists and Graphic Designers to produce 'Traffic', the Cornwall College youth lifestyle magazine, that is entirely written by you! Let's not forget our yearly London trip which includes three nights accommodation in a 3* London hotel, a meal in Planet Hollywood, being in a live TV studio audience, a private 3D IMAX screening, trip to the London Film Museum, a London Eye flight, West End show, shopping and much, much more.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
For this course you will need to have four GCSE passes at grade C or above, one of which must be English or Mathematics. We will also accept equivalent qualifications, for example a completed Level 2 Diploma. Mature learners will be considered on an individual basis.
Please enquire if you are at all unsure as to your suitability and we will be happy to discuss the course and its content with you.

course.mlo:objective:
The course will give you the tools that you need to create a fully costed and effective marketing plan.

  • Understand your markets and customers
  • Carry out market research
  • Understand pricing, promotion, products and place
  • Implement a range of marketing activities from the marketing mix

  • Gain a clear understanding of how to improve the return on investment with your marketing activities

Effective Marketing will be delivered through practical sessions, lectures and group discussions, using examples from real local businesses.

Information & Communication Technology
course.dc:title: CCNA Routing and Switching 1 - Introduction to Networks (Evenings)
course.learningOutcome: Progression onto CISCO CCNA Exploration - Routing Protocol and Concepts
course.mlo:objective:
This course runs for 15 weeks and comprise 30 hours guided learning within the Cisco Lab and, but also require the students to complete approx. 4 – 6 hours of home based online CISCO NetAcademy curriculum study a week. Each unit requires a student to achieve a 70% pass rate before progressing onto the next module, with each unit having to be studied succinctly.

Introduction to Networks introduces the architecture, structure, functions, components, and models of the internet and other computer networks. The principles and structure of IP addressing and the fundamentals of Ethernet concepts, media, and operations are introduced to provide a foundation for the curriculum. By the end of this part, you will be able to build simple LANs, perform basic configurations for routers and switches, and implement IP addressing schemes.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Students must have a broadband connection to the internet as the study material is only accessible online. The study material contains active content, which means that students will need to set up your firewall to allow pop-ups from the Cisco sites.

presentation.dc:subject: Information & Communication Technology

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description: This course provides a comprehensive, theoretical, and practical approach to learning the technologies and protocols needed to design and implement a converged switched network. Students learn about the hierarchical network design model and how to select devices for each layer. The course explains how to configure a switch for basic functionality and how to implement Virtual LANs, VTP, and Inter-VLAN routing in a converged network. The different implementations of Spanning Tree Protocol in a converged network are presented, and students develop the knowledge and skills necessary to implement a WLAN in a small-to-medium network.

course.mlo:prerequisite:

Students must have a broadband connection to the internet as the study material is only accessible online. The study material contains active content, which means that students will need to set up your firewall to allow pop-ups from the Cisco sites.

presentation.dc:title: CISCO CCNA Exploration 3 - LAN Switching and Wireless (Evening)

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description: This course discusses the WAN technologies and network services required by converged applications in enterprise networks. The course uses the Cisco Network Architecture to introduce integrated network services and explains how to select the appropriate devices and technologies to meet network requirements. Students learn how to implement and configure common data link protocols and how to apply WAN security concepts, principles of traffic, access control, and addressing services. Finally, students learn how to detect, troubleshoot, and correct common enterprise network implementation issues
course.dc:subject: IT, ICT, Information Technology, Systems, IT support, IT systems, WAN, wireless area network, wireless, wifi,
Information & Communication Technology
course.dc:title: CCNA Routing & Switching 4 - Connecting Networks (Evenings)
course.mlo:objective:
This unit runs for 15 weeks and comprise 30 hours guided learning within the Cisco Lab and, but also require the students to complete approx. 4 – 6 hours of home based online CISCO NetAcademy curriculum study a week. Each unit requires a student to achieve a 70% pass rate before progressing onto the next module, with each unit having to be studied succinctly.

Connecting Networksdiscusses the WAN technologies and network services required by converged applications in a complex network. Completing this part will enable you to understand the selection criteria of network devices and WAN technologies to meet network requirements. You will learn how to configure and troubleshoot network devices and resolve common issues with data link protocols. You will also develop the knowledge and skills needed to implement IPSec and virtual private network (VPN) operations in a complex network.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Prerequisites: CISCO CCNA Exploration Network Fundamentals, Routing Protocols and Concepts, and LAN Switching and Wireless

Students must have a broadband connection to the internet as the study material is only accessible online. The study material contains active content, which means that students will need to set up your firewall to allow pop-ups from the Cisco sites.

This course is intended for people who love reading and have their own stories to tell, both beginners and more experienced writers who feel in need of a little inspiration.  

Wednesdays from 6.30pm to 8.30pm

5 weeks  - 5th of October 2016 (start date changed)

5 weeks  - 22nd of February 2017

5 weeks - 26th of April 2017

Course fee - £50.00

Please ring 0845 22 32 567 or 01209 611622 to book your place on the course.
course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Creative Writing (JP)
course.abstract: Intended for people who have stories to tell, both beginners and more experienced writers who feel in need of a little inspiration.
course.learningOutcome: After the course you can enrol onto one of our other courses we offer.
course.mlo:objective:
The sessions are divided into discussions and writing exercises designed to stimulate the imagination and generate ideas.  Each week students take home a short story or life writing extract and the sessions begin with a discussion of its particular qualities.  Every workshop has a different focus, writing descriptively about place or to evoke a particular emotion or creating believable characters and convincing dialogue.  Students are encouraged to share their writing and, as they grow in confidence, to contribute constructive ideas on the writing of others.  One session is spent exploring the different aspects of genre writing and the course concludes with a short introduction to editing and re-writing.  If desired, one week is set aside for poetry.

If all this sounds a little daunting please don't be put off, whatever level your writing has reached, our groups are friendly and above all, very enjoyable.

presentation.dc:title: Creative Writing (Evening)

course.dc:description:
Puzzled by the huge range of artist's colours? This one-day Colour Mixing Workshop for Beginners explains which are the must-haves and which are the ones you can do without, and how to get the most out of this basic range in terms of mixing them.

Saturdays from 10.00am to 3.30pm.

Saturday 11th of March 2017

Saturday 13th of May 2017

Fee per workshop - £33.00

Please ring 0845 22 32 567 or 01209 611622 to book your place on the course.
course.dc:subject: Cornwall College
course.dc:title: Colour Mixing Workshop (JP)
course.abstract: Learn how to get the most out of a basic range of paint colours
course.learningOutcome: You can do one of our other recreational workshops or courses.
course.mlo:objective:
Understanding  how to use paint involves knowing a certain amount of colour theory, so hand in hand with using the materials, you'll be finding out about primary and secondary colours, complementary, tonal values, neutrals and tints, and discovering how the theories behave with the actual stuff!

The workshop is designed for painters in either oils or acrylics.  For reasons of drying times, acrylics are an easier option for the day, and quality artist's acrylics will be supplied, but everything you learn on the course will apply equally to oils.  Please bring overalls, paint-rags, some brushes, and a palette and palette knife for mixing, if you have them.

course.dc:title: British Sign Language SIGNAT Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Once you have successfully completed this course you can use sign language in everyday life for business and social communication. You may wish to progress onto British Sign Language Level 3 NVQ.
course.mlo:objective: This course is designed to enable students to acquire more knowledge of British Sign Language and should enable you to: participate in a conversation using sign language without frequent repetition or misunderstanding; demonstrate an appropriate selection of vocabulary and grammatical principles; convey information clearly and accurately; understand a signed narrative without major omissions or inaccuracies; respond accurately to signed questions relating to a signed narrative; describe the content of a sequence of pictures using sign language; demonstrate a range of vocabulary clearly and accurately and demonstrate a selection of grammatical principles clearly and accurately.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants for this course should ideally have passed the Stage 1 examination and will be expected to be familiar with the Stage 1 British Sign Language curriculum. If you at all unsure as to your suitability for this course then please enquire and the programme manager will be able to discuss this with you as entry for this course is at the discretion of the course manager if you do not have the stated entry requirements.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Duchy College has been training within the childrens workforce for over 17 years. We have past students working in a range of employment positions and provisions including Nursery, Primary, Pre school settings throughout Devon and Cornwall, as well as other careers within the childrens workforce.

We aim to set high standards in our teaching in order to ensure that our students when they qualify, are striving for outstanding practice in their work settings. We have trained whole staff teams at levels 2, 3 and 4 in settings which, as a result of their excellent practice, have been graded by Ofsted as Outstanding; these settings have included locally Pensilva Pre School, Ducklings Pre School, Kingfisher Nursery.

Our teaching and assessment team are all experienced practitioners and have all worked within the Early Years sector in positions such as Nursery and Pre School Managers, Primary Teaching, Forest School Leader, Private Nanny and Home Based Child Care. All teaching staff undertake regular professional updating within their chosen sector ensuring that students have the most up to date teaching available.

All students who work with children are required to have a DBS check prior to starting the course which costs in the region of £44 (this can be arranged through the college).

This course is for applicants who wish to gain Early Years Educator status as a fully qualified member of the Early Years team in roles such as Keyperson, Nursery or Pre-School Supervisor in employment within the Early Years Sector or to progress on to Higher level qualfications that lead to careers in other areas of the Children and Young people's Workforce.

 

Some applicants will already hold a level 2 Certificate for the Children and Young People's Workforce, others may be volunteering, as yet unqualified, and wish to become employed or to count towards level 3 staff to child ratios in the setting. The profile of learner is often parents who wish to return to the workforce with a change of career which supports their family commitments to children who are at nursery or school. The course mirrors the school day in terms of term times and hours of delivery.
course.dc:subject: Early Years
course.dc:title: Early Years Practitioner (Early Years Educator) CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Gain Early Years Educator status or progress to higher qualifications
course.learningOutcome: Students can go into employment within the Early Years Sector in positions within Primary Schools, Nursery or Pre-Schools, among other settings. The Diploma for the Early Years Practitioner (Early Years Educator) is considered a full and relevant qualification for working with children aged birth to 7 years. Those who successfully gain the full Diploma may progress into Higher Education by undertaking the Foundation Degree for the Children and Young People's Workforce
course.mlo:objective:
Your course includes weekly attendance at college, for one day each week from 9am - 2.30pm, term time only. At college you will study the Mandatory units which make up the Early Years Educator which include: Developing Effective Study Skills; Promote Partnership working with parents;  Model, promote and support positive behaviour with chidlren; Principles of Safeguarding policies and procedures in the early years sector; Working in partnership with colleagues and other professionals in early years settings; Plan and implement activities, play opportunities and educational programmes in an early years setting; Promoting childrens health and welfare in an early years setting; Promoting health and safety of children;Promote childrens speech and language and communication development; Support organisational requiremetns for recording storing and disclosing information and providing reports in an early years setting; mSupporting chidlrens creative and imaginative play experiences; Supporting chidlren experiencing transitions and significant events in the early years sector; Continuous professional development using Reflective Practice; Theories which underpin practice in the Early years sector; Child Development from conception to 7 years 11 months; Observation and assessment in the Early years. 

 In addition to attendance at college you will receive regular assessments of written assignment work , portfolio evidence and observations of your working practice within your work setting.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants should ideally have achieved GCSE Grade C in English and Maths before they start the course, but could study these alongside the level 3.  Employers will ask to see your GCSE results and can only include level 3 qualified staff in their higher staff:child ratios if they hold ‘C’ grade English Language and maths.  Throughout the course you will need to be either employed or be volunteering in an Early Years setting for at least 2 half days or one full day each week whilst attending college on one day.  This needs to increase to 2 days each week once the attendance at college ceases in July of the first year.  You will need to have gained approximately 700 hours in an early years setting whilst you are working towards your qualification.

People who are either working in a care role or who want to move into a care role but need some experience before applying. It's a module that anyone who has an interest in the human body could do, and also is good as a foundation/refresher for anyone going on to study any course that involves physiology, pathology or human biology.
course.dc:title: The Biology of Health
course.learningOutcome: This module is part of the FdSc in healthcare practice. You may wish to carry on your studies and undertake the full foundation degree this would then equip you with the relevant qualifications to be considered for a band 4 post (assistant practitioner) within a care setting.
course.mlo:objective:
The course is fact based and will cover:

  • Human Growth and Development
  • How normal body functions are maintained   throughout life including
  • The nature and role of blood,
  • The rate and depth of breathing,
  • The nervous system,
  • The different types of hormones,
  • The liver, blood sugars and metabolism,
  • Water balance and the function of the kidneys.

 

 

 

 

You will be encouraged to read around the subject and, where possible, put into practice your new learning and understanding. There is an in-class test  and you will be required to write a short case study.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Yyou should be in a care role (or wanting to move into a care role or strengthen application for a health or biology /psychology based degree. Have a level 3 qualifiation, level 2 in English and Maths (preferable).

Each learner will be contacted by a Guidance Mentor to ensure that this is the right course for them and to help prepare them for the course.

presentation.dc:title: The Biology of Health

If you have a passion for Sport or Fitness and the desire to gain the necessary knowledge, skills and work-related experience to work in the industry then this course will be the right career move for you to provide you with the opportunity to study as well as work in the industry.

Modules

Year 1

  • Personal & Employability Skills Development (20 credits)
  • Business for Sport (10 credits)
  • Long Term Athlete Development (10 credits)
  • Performance Analysis (10 credits)
  • Health Promotion (20 credits)
  • Human Exercise Science (20 credits)
  • Sports Coaching (20 credits)
  • Research Skills (10 credits)

Year 2

  • Research Project (20 credits)
  • Nutrition (20 credits)
  • Sport Psychology (20 credits)
  • Applied Sports Development (20 credits)
  • Advanced Sports Coaching (20 credits)
  • Conditioning for Performance (20 credits)
course.dc:subject: FdSc, sport coaching, sports development, fitness training, fitness testing, fitness, PE Teaching, personal training, leadership, sport science, competitive sport, rugby, football, netball, athletics, hockey, basketball, sports psychology, sports therapy, coach, coaching, instructor, fitness instructor
Sport
course.dc:title: Sports Development and Coaching UOPLY FdSc Level 5
course.abstract: FdSc Sports Development and Coaching
course.learningOutcome: On successful completion of the course you will have the opportunity to carry on with your education by taking the final year of an honours degree or move into employment in the expanding world of sports development and coaching. The programme and specifically its work-based elements will provide you with excellent opportunities to network for your future career.
course.mlo:objective:
The course has been designed with the UK Coaching Certificate guidelines at its core, so you will be engaged in the advancement of your coaching ability, while gaining your degree.

Opportunities are provided to develop your knowledge of the science behind coaching across a range of modules that allow you to apply the underpinning theories and put them into practice.

Learning methods include working as part of a group or as an individual throughout the programme to develop your employability and academic skills. Working with local school groups and organising events within the community will be part of your study. You will also conduct lab-based experiments e.g. dissections and practical fitness testing and training to investigate the effects of exercise on the body systems.

The programme may provide opportunities for you to gain relevant National Governing Body qualifications in, for example:

  • FA Level 1
  • CYQ Level 2 Gym Instructor
  • CYQ LEVEL 3 Personal Trainer
  • MIAS Mountain Bike Leaders

Valuable work-related experience is undertaken as part of the programme to develop your employability skills and experience to ensure that you meet the needs of your future career choice and employers.

A partnership with a well-established UK activity centre provides the opportunity for you to undertake a paid summer placement from April or May to September in your first year

The course has been designed with the UK Coaching Certificate guidelines at its core, so students will be engaged in the advancement of their coaching ability, while gaining the foundation degree. The course will provide opportunities for students to gain relevant NGBs in sport, (e.g. FA Level 1 & HSLA), fitness (e.g. CYQ L2 Gym Instructor & L3 Personal Trainer) and outdoor (e.g. MIAS Mountain Bike Leaders or GNAS Level 1 Archery). 

Valuable work-related experience is undertaken as part of the course to develop your employability skills and experience to ensure that you meet the needs of your future career choice and employers.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
120 UCAS points from AS and A-Levels (at least 80 points must be at A2-level) or relevant level 3 qualification i.e. BTEC National Diploma/BTEC Extended Diploma - PPP Grades required. Access to HE Diplomas - 45 credits at level 3.  Plus GCSEs at grade C or above in English language and mathematics: alternatives at Level 2 may be considered.

Potential students must be prepared to be actively involved with the many practical opportunities whilst on the course.

Mature applicants with relevant experience but without the stated qualifications will be considered individually and are encouraged to apply.

Previous learning and experience may be credited. If in doubt, call 0845 22 32 567 or email enquiries@cornwall.ac.uk.

A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme. It is your responsibility to undertake this before commencing your study.

course.mlo:objective:

  • Equality, diversity and inclusion
  • Personal development

 They do not confirm competence but relate to the knowledge elements covered in the mandatory units of the Health and Social Care Diploma at L3. They can be used as standalone qualifications or as part of the Apprenticeship in Health & Social Care at Level 3.

College sessions are provided and assessment is by assignment.

course.dc:description:
This course can be available across all our localities at Camborne, St Austell and Saltash and may also be available at other locations.

Various start dates are available.

Please contact us for fees and funding information.

The Level 3 Diploma in Dental Nursing focuses on direct chair side work and support during a range of dental treatments: the student would need to have some considerable knowledge and skills in relation to dental equipment, instruments and materials and be able to work as a key member of the oral healthcare team. The course has been built on a number of principles: encourage access by those groups of staff for whom they are designed; promote good quality practice and high quality services; help the sector respond to changing requirements; encourage transfer and progression; be consistent with future legislation for statutory registration.

This course is suitable for 16 plus who have an employed position in Dental Nursing. It consists of 15 units, plus an online mandatory examination that assesses underpinning knowledge.

The units studied are all mandatory.

This course is offered as a Level 3 Diploma in Dental Nursing (City and Guilds). We also offer the apprenticeship route, contact us for more information.
course.dc:subject: dental, dentist,
Health & Social Care
course.dc:title: Dental Nursing CG Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Level 3 Dental Nursing Diploma
course.learningOutcome: On completion of the course you will become a qualified dental nurse to be registered with the GDC.
course.mlo:objective:
You will study the following units

  • Emergency First Aid Skills
  • Ensure your own actions reduce risks to health and safety
  • Prepare and maintain environment, instruments, and equipment for clinical dental procedures
  • Offer information and support to individuals on the protection of their oral health
  • Provide chairside support during the assessment of patients' oral health
  • Contribute to the production of dental images
  • Provide chairside support during the prevention and control of periodontal disease and caries and the restoration of cavities
  • Provide chairside support during the provision of fixed and removable prostheses
  • Provide chairside support during non-surgical endodontic treatment
  • Provide chairside support during the extraction of teeth and minor oral surgery
  • Principles of infection control in the dental environment
  • Assessment of oral health and treatment planning
  • Dental radiography
  • Scientific principles in the management of oral health diseases and dental
 Classes are provided in College. Assessment is via a portfolio of evidence, observations in the workplace and an online examination.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You need to be working in a dental practice.

Initial assessments and an interview will be required.

course.dc:description: A Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check will be a mandatory requirement after you have been accepted on the programme, which the College will support you with.

This course is suitable for learners who work or want to work as an Assistant Practitioner in Healthcare and related services and who want to extend their knowledge, skills and potential to earn and people new to working in care who have completed recent academic study and/or experience.
course.dc:title: Assistant Practitioners in Healthcare CG Diploma Level 5 (Higher Apprenticeship)
course.learningOutcome: On completion of this qualification, learners may progress onto further qualifications specific to their work context. A wide range of qualifications are available such as higher education qualifications or other work-related education and training to support Continuing Professional Development.
course.mlo:objective:
To achieve the Level 5 Diploma for Assistant Practitioners in Healthcare, learners must achieve 120 credits studying a range of units such as:

Safeguarding, professional development, functions of the body, communication, health and saftey, nutrition and fluid balance, principles and philosophy of healthcare, equality, diversity and inclusion, infection prevention and control. You will also undertake a research project as well as employment and personal learning skills.

Learners will attend College 1 day a month, with additional support sessions planned throughout the year, with the rest of your course and work based skills being carried out in the workplace.

Throughout the programme of study  learners will be assigned an assessor who will carry out observations in the workplace against set competences, as well as meet with your mentor to discuss progress.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Applicants should be employed for at least 15 hours (2 days) per week in the healthcare sector.  For learners not employed in a setting where they will be able to learn and practice clinical skills, a weekly placement for the duration of the course will need to be arranged with a suitable mentor to support them through the practice elements of the programme. Learners will be supported by the appropriate College staff to find a suitable placement. This will need to be agreed with the Course Manager on application with a supporting letter from your employer/work placement provider.

In addition learners should have a minimum of a relevant level 3 qualification or equivalent and preferably have previous experience of working or volunteering in a care or health setting. GCSEs required at grade C or above in English language and mathematics.

This qualification fulfils the regulatory requirement for managers of adult residential and domiciliary services and replaces the NVQ Level 4 care and the leadership and management qualifications.

course.mlo:objective:

    • Communication
    • Professional Development
    • Equality, Diversity and Inclusion
    • Health, Safety and Risk Management
    • Working in Partnership in Health and Social Care
    • Lead and manage a team
    • Develop professional supervision
    • Lead Practice that supports positive outcomes
    • Safeguarding and Protection of Vulnerable Adults
    • Lead Person-Centred Practice
    • Recruitment and Selection
    • Facilitate Coaching and Mentoring
    • Manage Induction in Health and Social Care
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You need to be already working in health and social care as a manager or assistant / deputy manager. You will be responsible for running a facility that provides services for adults and have a good level of literacy.

Initial assessments and an interview will be required prior to being accepted onto this course.

course.dc:title: Contribute to Health and Safety in Health and Social Care Taster
course.learningOutcome: Opportunities for progression onto a wide range of formal qualifications offered by Cornwall College within the Health and Social Care subject area.
course.mlo:objective:
This course will give you some understanding of the knowledge and skills required to carry out work safely including :-

  •  Own responsibilities, and the responsibilities of others, relating to health and safety in health and social care

  • The use of risk assessments in relation to health and safety in health and social care

  • Procedures for responding to accidents and sudden illness

  • How to reduce the spread of infection

  • How to move and handle equipment and other objects safety

  • How to handle hazardous substances and materials

  • How to promote fire safety in the work setting

  • How to manage own stress
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no entry requirements, just an interest in the subject whether from a professional or personal viewpoint.

course.dc:description: You must provide proof of identification (eg passport, driving licence, birth certificate) to the instructor before completion of the course.

This course is for individuals who want to achieve a qualification recognised by employers as an Emergency First Aider. This qualification covers the syllabus as outlined by the Health & Saftey Executive (HSE) and is a nationally recogonised qualification.

You will be gaining knowledge and competence to administer first aid and basic life support - an extremely valuable life skill to have.
course.dc:subject: Emergency First Aid at work
course.dc:title: Emergency First Aid at Work FAA Award Level 2 (QCF)
course.learningOutcome:
Assessment is based on practical and oral assessment throughout the course and successful completion of a written test at the end of the course.

Certificates last for 3 years and to renew you need to retake the full course. It is recommended that, during the 3 year period, you attend an annual refresher course.

 You can attend a 3 day appointed First Aider at work course.
course.mlo:objective:
Course content

This course is made up of a theoretical and practical session to include

  • Responsibilities & reporting
  • assessment of the situation
  • Choking
  • Dealing with an unresponsive casualty
  • Minor injuries
  • Bleeding control
  • Seizures
  • Infection control
  • Reuscitation
  • Recovery position
  • hock
  • Safe use of equipment
course.mlo:prerequisite: Applicants must be 16 and over

teachers, child minders, creche assistants, playgroup personnel and anyone else who has a responsibility for their welfare

whilst in your care.

course.dc:title: Emergency Paediatric First Aid FAA Award Level 3 (1 Day)
course.learningOutcome:
CERTIFICATION

Assessment is ongoing by the instructor in respect of the learner's practical skills and there will be a multiple choice question paper to answer in respect of the learners  knowledge.

A three year certificate will be issued, subject to assessment.

Learners can enrole in Paediartic First Aid FAA Award Level 3 (2 day) but will only need to attend the second day to cover unit 2
course.mlo:objective:

  • Responsibilities and reporting
  • Assessment of the emergency situation
  • Dealing with an unresponsive casualty
  • Recusitation
  • Choking
  • Control of bleeding and shock
  • Recovery position
  • Anaphylaxis
  • Epilepsy
  • Fainting
  • Infection control
  • Minor injuries
  • First Aid equipment

DURATION

A minimum of 6 hours makes up this unit consisting of theoretical and practical work.
course.mlo:prerequisite: A learner must be a minimum of 16 years of age to qualify.

course.dc:description:
Swedish massage is the most common and best known type of massage in the west.  It is thought to reduce pain, joint stiffness and poor circulation and is the basis for other types of massage including sports massage.

This course is suitable for people who are serious about practicing professionally as a therapist in Swedish massage and is a good grounding for other types of massage. Applicants may be looking to advance in their profession.
course.dc:subject: Swedish Massage Beauty Therapy Holistic
Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Swedish Massage VTCT Certificate Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
After this course, you will be qualified to perform professional Swedish massage treatments for clients via employment or self-employment in the beauty therapy or complementary therapy industry.

There is also the prospect of moving onto one of our other specialist massage qualifications such as Sports massage or you may choose to compliment your skills with other Holistic therapy qualifications such as Aromatherapy or Reflexology.
course.mlo:objective:
This VTCT qualification will enable you to gain the skills, knowledge and understanding required to perform Swedish massage treatments for clients.  It is an intensive course in which you will learn the five massage strokes; effleurage, kneading, rhythmic tapping, friction and vibration/shaking.

Not only do you learn how to massage professionally, you will also learn health, safety and hygiene, basic anatomy and physiology, preparing the treatment area and consultation techniques.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
For this course, you will need a good standard of English and the ability and motivation to self-study as this is a fast track course that requires the student to study to a high standard.  You should also hold a level 2 qualification in beauty or massage.

If you are unsure as to whether or not you meet the requirements, please call the Hair and Beauty Department and ask to speak to the course manager who will be happy to discuss this with you.
