course.dc:description: Contact us for more information.

Under the Licensing Act 2003, anyone authorising the retail sale of alcohol will have to hold a personal licence. In order to qualify for a personal licence, an applicant must hold a licensing qualification which is: Qualifications and Curriculum Authority (QCA) accredited, and Government approved.

BIIABs new qualification, the BIIAB Level 2 Award for Personal Licence Holders, is both QCA accredited and Government approved, and has been specifically designed to meet the statutory requirements of the Licensing Act 2003.
course.dc:subject: Personal Licence Holders, Award, BIIAB, Licensing, 2003, Alcohol, hospitality, city and guilds, drink, CG, C&G, city & guilds
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Personal Licence Holders BIIAB Award Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
On successful assessment the candidate will receive a national qualification awarded by the BIIAB, which is recognised as evidence of the applicants knowledge and understanding of licensing law and the social responsibilities associated with running licensed premises.

The BIIAB Level 2 Award for Personal Licence Holders is a nationally recognised qualification designed for anyone authorising the retail sale of alcohol in licensed premises including:

  • Public Houses
  • Convenience stores
  • Bars
  • Sports and social clubs
  • Hotels
  • Entertainment establishments
  • Restaurants
  • Nightclubs
  • Off-licences
  • Leisure parks
  • Supermarkets
  • Casinos and any other venue or site where alcohol is sold
course.mlo:objective:
BIIAB´s Level 2 Award for Personal Licence Holders covers the syllabus set by Government, to enable candidates to understand the law in relation to:

  • The roles, responsibilities and functions of licensing authorities within the framework of the licensing objectives.
  • The application process for a personal licence.
  • The role and legal responsibilities of the personal licence holder, and the penalties relating to failure to comply with the law.
  • The premises licence.
  • The content and purpose of operating schedules.
  • The role and duties of the designated premises supervisor.
  • The unauthorised licensable activities.
  • The permitted temporary licensable activities.
  • The rights of entry to licensed premises.
  • The police powers with regard to suspension and closure of licensed premises.
  • The specific prohibitions for the sale of alcohol.
  • The strengths of alcoholic drinks, and the effects of alcohol on the human body.
  • The protection of children from harm.
  • The responsible retail sale of alcohol.
course.mlo:prerequisite: In order to be eligible to apply for a personal licence a person must:, - Be 18 years of age or above. - Possess an accredited licensing qualification. - Not have forfeited a personal licence in the preceding 5 year period. - Must not have any unspent convictions for any relevant offences in either England or Wales or for any foreign offences.

presentation.dc:title: Personal Licence Holders Award Level 2

course.dc:description:
This course is the first step for learners who are looking at starting a career in the Hairdressing industry.

You will learn the basic techniques of shampooing & conditioning, cutting, styling,  and / or colouring & perming alongside customer care, health & safety and retail product knowledge & sales.  
This hairdressing certificate gives you the basic techniques and experience to start a career in the hairdressing industry.

The study program will consist of practical salons and classroom based theory sessions. There will be theory written papers taken in exam conditions and practical assessments which are carried out during practical lessons on paying clients.
course.dc:subject: Hair & Beauty
course.dc:title: Women's Hairdressing CG Certificate Level 2
course.abstract: Hairdressing
course.learningOutcome:
A Hairdressing Certificate at Level 2 will give you the practical skills and knowledge to get your first job in the hairdressing industry. You could continue your studies with Cornwall College by upgrading to level 2, 3, and 4 qualifications in hair or diversify into beauty. Cornwall College offer pathways in hair and beauty, and you could choose to study, full time or as an apprentice.
Once you have the right set of qualifications, they could take you all over the world. Past students have gone on to manage their own salon, travel on cruise liners, work in the world of television or as session stylists at photographic shoots
course.mlo:objective:
Whichever Cornwall College you choose, you will be learning in purpose-built salons, open to the public and training in a fastpaced and creative environment.
Each of the salons are run by professional stylists and the lecturers are happy to share their expertise with you. You will develop your practical salon skills, from learning how to identify and carry out different cuts to learning how to achieve the latest looks through colouring and styling techniques. Enhance your skills in customer service and client care in the salon and at reception with making appointments and the promotion of retail products and services. Everything you need to know to begin your career as a hairdresser is covered on this course.
Assessments are carried out during practical lessons along with some on-line testing.
If you are 16-19 you will continue to develop your skills of Maths, English, Employability and Work Experience as a part of your study program.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You will need to have a minimum of 2 GCSEs at grade c, in English and Maths or an equivalent qualification.

At Cornwall College, we recognise that applicants can often offer a high level of competence as well as life experience and we will therefore consider all applications on their merits alongside their qualifications.

If you are unsure as to whether or not you meet the requirements, please call the Hairdressing  Department and ask to speak to the course manager who will be happy to discuss it with you.

course.dc:description:
This course is a 20 credit module (CORC156) from a Foundation Degree, awarded by Plymouth University.

Contact us for more information.
This course is ideal for anybody involved in planning, delivering or evaluating events; or for those aspiring to work as event managers or coordinators with no previous experience.
course.dc:subject: Event management, performance boosting, short course, performance boosting, short courses, degree level short course, planning marketing, dlsc event planning wedding planning managing an event
Catering & Hospitality
course.dc:title: Event Management (VC)
course.learningOutcome:
There are several flexible progression opportunities for delegates onto other degree level short courses, including: Effective marketing; Principles of event design & themes; Festivals and many more. Alternatively you may be interested in the full time FdA Event Management awarded by the University of Plymouth.

Training at all levels and in a range of subjects is available through Cornwall College Business.
course.mlo:objective:
You will gain a clear understanding of the core operational requirements of designing, planning and running events. Take away practical skills as well as your own bespoke event management guide which is developed during the sessions with the needs of your business at the centre.

The course includes:

  • Types of events
  • Event operations and procedures
  • Customer service
  • Selling
  • Sponsorship and funding
  • Managing event suppliers and contractors
  • Event safety
  • Quality in event production
  • Market size and structure
  • Industry background
  • Market trends.

Managing Event Operation is delivered through practical sessions, lectures, group discussions and site visits. Delegates will have access to online support materials and a designated tutor for learning support. Delegates will have to undertake an assignment to successfully past this course.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements for this course.

course.mlo:objective: Basic health and safety rules will be covered along with how lead sheet can be manipulated and formed to a variety of shapes used in roofing applications by using hand tools and cold working techniques.  On completion of the course students will know the health and safety procedures for working with lead sheet and be able to form lead work details by bossing lead sheet to shape.

course.learningOutcome: This course will progress on to Lead Welding Fabrication Course.
course.mlo:objective: Basic health and safety rules will be covered along with details about fitting lead sheet that requires the metal to be cut and welded to another sheet, perhaps to protect where there is a projection through a roof such as a pipe or chimney.  Lead sheets are welded together by the controlled melting of lead rods on to the join to bond the sheets together and provide a homogenous joint.  It is a relatively soft and very dense metal when compared to other metals used in roofing such as copper or zinc.
course.mlo:prerequisite: This course follows on from Basic Lead Appreciation Course.

course.dc:description:
Changes to ACS Gas Scheme

As from 1st February 2010 all engineers who undertake initial or re-assessment for Boilers (CEN1) or Fires (HTR1) must hold a valid Combustion Performance Analysers qualification (CPA1).

Engineers who currently hold valid certificates for Boilers (CEN1) or Fires (HTR1) have until 1st April 2012 to obtain the Combustion Performance Analysers qualification (CPA1).

If a Combustion Performance Analyses qualification (CPA1) is not held after this date the Gas Safe Register will be suspended.

Therefore, all candidates who wish to attend the ACS Gas assessments must provide a copy of their current/expired Domestic and CPA1 qualification.
This course is for qualified gas engineers wishing to renew or extend their qualifications and also for new entrants to gain their qualification on domestic gas fires.
You will be assessed at Cornwall College Saltash.

Construction Trades

Candidates can then apply for:

  • Central Heating - CEN1
  •  Water Heaters - WAT1
  •  Cookers- CKR1
  • Meters – MET1
  • Combustion performance Analysers – CPA1
  • Energy Efficiency - EE1
  • LPG Changeover from Natural Gas – CoNGLP1
  • Residential Park Homes – CoNGLP1/RPH
  • Leisure Activity Vehicles/Widney Fires – CoNGLP1/LAV and HTRLP2
  • Boats – CoNGLP1/B
course.mlo:objective:
You will undertake both theoretical and practical assessments of competency.

The Assessment which will be taken are:
HTR1 - Fires
course.mlo:prerequisite: You must already be a qualified gas engineer who currently hold CCN1 and CPA1 analysers.

Therefore, all candidates who wish to attend the ACS Gas assessments must provide a copy of their current/expired Domestic and CPA1 qualification.

This course is for qualified gas installation engineers/plumbers seeking re-certification of expired qualifications.  This is also suitable for engineers wanting to be gas qualified for the first time but must have a minimum of NVQ level-2 plumbing with experience of working alongside a qualified gas engineer.
course.dc:subject: Domestic Gas Safety CCN1 central heating boliers CEN1 water heaters WAT1 cookers CKR1 space heaters fires HTR1 ACOPs

course.dc:title: Domestic Gas Package CCN1, CENWAT, HTR1, CKR1
course.learningOutcome:
This course is a legal requirement for any person who wishes to carry out work on domestic gas appliances.  Also successful candidates will be able to apply for Gas Safe registration and carry out Gas Safety Checks, install, commission and service appliances. 

Candidates can then apply for:

  • Combustion performance Analysers - CPA1 (can taken during this course is required)
  • Meters - MET1
  • Energy Efficiency - EE1
  • LPG Changeover from Natural Gas - CoNGLP1
  • Residential Park Homes - CoNGLP1/RPH
  • Leisure Activity Vehicles/Widney Fires - CoNGLP1/LAV and HTRLP2
  • Boats - CoNGLP1/B
course.mlo:objective:
You will undertake both theoretical and practical assessments of competency.  Training guidance prior to undertaking the assessments is available if required and the candidate must demonstrate competence in Core Gas Safety before proceeding to appliance assessments.   Assessments are carried out by multiple choice papers and practical assessments.  The Assessments which will be taken are:

 

CCN1 - Core Gas Safety (Natural Gas)

CENWAT - Central Heating Boilers & Water Heaters

HTR1 - Space Heaters (Fires)

CKR1 - Cookers
course.mlo:prerequisite: For these courses you will need an existing ACOP's or ACS qualification alternatively a minimum of NVQ level-2 in plumbing with relevant on-site experience. Evidence of qualifications and work experience must be provided prior to undertaking assessments. Please enquire if you are at all unsure as to your suitability for this course and the programme manager will be able to discuss this with you.

course.dc:description: Following the revised Building Regulations published April 2005, from April 2006, all installers wishing to certify their own work under Gas Safe Registration legislation, (rather than call Local Authority Building Control) must hold a certificate in Energy Efficiency for Domestic Heating. This course can help you deliver your responsibilities under the Home Energy Conservation Act.  This course is also suitable for engineers working on renewable energies and wish to be registered under the NICEIC MCS Micro Certification Scheme.

The training is aimed at both experienced and new installers, and consists of a daylong workshop covering a range of topics, including the new building regulations, climate change and High Efficiency Condensing boilers. This is followed by a simple 90-minute multiple-choice test, which if you pass, gives you the new certificate. Candidates shall receive training material three weeks before the training for self study.
course.dc:subject: EE1 Energy Efficiency gas domestic
Construction Trades
course.dc:title: Energy Efficiency Building Regulations L1 NICEIC
course.learningOutcome: You will be able to certify you own work under Gas Safe Register.
course.mlo:objective: This is a one day course and the content includes topics such as: Benefits of efficient heating and hot water, Energy efficiency and the building regulations, The importance of boiler efficiency, The importance of an efficient hot water cylinder, Domestic heating and hot water controls and Commissioning. It is for registered engineers who intend to provide energy advice in the home, develop additional energy advice-giving skills, understand fuel poverty, understand the importance of energy efficiency and how to refer householders for additional assistance.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Candidates must have one of the following qualifications; Appropriate NVQ Level 3/BTEC or equivalent Appropriate industry registration scheme: e.g. Gas Safe Register or OFTEC-105E or equivalent. At least two years industry experience of installation of domestic heating and hot water systems currently un-certificated skills equivalent NVQ Level 3. At least two years industry experience of design and advice services of domestic heating and hot water systems at NVQ Level 3 or equivalent. Please enquire if you are at all unsure as to your suitability on 01209 616349 and we will be happy to discuss the course with you.

The PASMA photocard provides proof that you have undergone and successfully completed training to a nationally recognised standard.  Many workplaces will insist on seeing your PASMA photo card before you will be allowed to assemble, alter or dismantle mobile access towers, so it should be retained with you at all times and presented for inspection by anyone in authority.

Contact us for more information.
Anyone who assembles, dismantles or alters a mobile tower.   Or anyone wishing to go into this field.
course.dc:subject: tower scaffolding, height, construction, PASMA, towers, advanced, guardrail, system, AGS
course.dc:title: Tower Scaffolding Level 1
course.mlo:objective:
This is mainly a practical course, with classroom based tutorials and the use of  DVDs and group participation combined with practical exercises. Delegates must successfully pass both sections - firstly a practical session looking at the assembly of a tower as well as carrying out specific inspections and including a safe dismantling of a structure. The theory includes the work at height regulations, site inspections and procedures.

Introduction to Mobile Access Towers
2. Tower Assembly
3. Stability
4. Safe Use of Towers
5. Repositioning Towers
6. Tower Inspection
7. Care & Maintenance
8. Tower Dismantle
9. Regulations and Standards

Health & Safety legislation & regulations.
PASMA Code of Practise.
Safe working at heights.
Identifying mobile access tower equipment.
Manufactures Instruction Manuals.
Ground and site conditions.
Sequence of erecting and dismantling mobile access towers.
Use of stabilisers, outriggers, sole pads and ties.
Moving and repositioning erected towers.
Inspection report procedure.
Multi choice test paper.
Advanced Guardrails and Through the Trap erection.
Practical erection, moving, inspection and dismantling
course.mlo:prerequisite: As this can be physically demanding applicants need to be fit and able to work at heights.

presentation.dc:title: Tower Scaffolding PASMA

course.mlo:objective:
During this course, you will gain up to date knowledge of current Water Regulations:

  • Water Regulations 1999
  • Pipework and fittings
  • Tightness testing
  • Cleansing and flushing of water systems
  • Commissioning

Water Regulations prevent misuse, waste, undue consumption or erroneous measurement of water and, most importantly, to prevent contamination of drinking water.

You will be provided with a comprehensive learning package followed by a 1/2-day assessment.

course.dc:description:
This course is intended to be delivered  as part of the suite of qualifications in Environmental Technologies and is free of charge to those who enrol also onto any of the following

 

Level 3 Award in the Installation and Maintenance of Solar Thermal Hot Water Systems 

Level 3 Award in the Installation and Maintenance of Heat Pump Systems (Non-refrigerant circuits) 

Level 3 Award in the Installation and Maintenance of Water Harvesting and Re-use Systems 

However this Award needs to be completed prior to enrolling onto the above

This course is ideal if you wish to have a career within the environmental technology sector.  It will provide you with a breadth of knowledge enabling you to move on to complete qualifications in a range of renewable energy technologies. It is important to note that you must complete this foundation module to be able to progress onto any of the following:

  • Solar Thermal Hot Water Systems
  • Heat Pump Systems
  • Water Harvesting and Re-use Systems

Engineering
course.dc:title: Environmental Technology Systems Awareness City & Guilds Award Level 3 (QCF)
course.abstract: A wide ranging course that will introduce you to a range of technologies
course.learningOutcome: On successfully completing the course you will be able to continue to gain more qualifications in specific areas of environmental technologies.
course.mlo:objective:
This course is designed to develop a broad understanding of environmental technologies. It will arm you with the knowledge and theory to give advice to customers on suitable environmental technology systems. You will learn about:

 1. Solar Thermal

2. Ground Source Heat Pumps

3. Air Source Heat Pumps

4. Biomass

5. Solar PV

6. Micro Wind

7. Micro Hydro

8. Combined Heat & Power (CHP)

9. Rainwater Harvesting

10. Greywater Use

This course is delivered over 1 day with an on-line exam at the end
course.mlo:prerequisite:
It is likely that you will be a qualified plumber, electrician or a practicing domestic installer or Domestic Energy Assessor / Home Energy Advisor or equivalent.

It is possible to take this course if you are not an established professional; however you will need to gain competence gas engineer or a plumber before you can complete some of the latter modules and gain a full qualification.

However if you are simply looking for a strong grounding in this industry and its principle technologies then this course could be ideal.

course.dc:description:
On-Site Assessment and Training (OSAT) helps experienced workers get the qualifications to prove they can do the job. It turns their existing skills and experience into a nationally recognised qualification such as an NVQ or SVQ. Having these qualifications also helps qualify them for a Construction Skills Certification Scheme (CSCS) card

On-site Assessment and Training (OSAT) is a method of assessing the skills and knowledge of people in the workplace and helps turns their existing skills and experience into a NVQ

The OSAT method involves a Construction assessor visiting the learner's place of work or site and working with them to build up a portfolio of evidence that prove their skills and knowledge. This route generally takes four or five visits over a period of approximately 6 to 12 months dependent on experience

OSAT training is ideal for learners who have some experience of their trade or profession and wish to gain a qualification to support their experience.

course.learningOutcome: After completing OSAT you will have the qualifications to match your experience.
course.mlo:objective: You will be visited at your site of employment and complete vaious modules of training, related to your current responsibilities.

course.dc:description: It is aimed at practising electricians who have not carried out inspection and testing since qualifying or who require some update training before going on to achieve the City & Guilds Level 3 Certificate in inspection, testing and certification of electrical installations (2391-10). It is also suitable for those with limited experience of inspection and testing of electrical installations, such as those:, Entering the industry from other engineering disciplines, Working in allied trades
You will study this course by attending College for three hours each week, for duration of ten weeks.
course.dc:subject: Fundamental Inspection Testing Initial Verification 2392 Electrical
Engineering
course.dc:title: Fundamental Inspection, Testing and Initial Verification City & Guilds Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome: You will be able to go on to achieve the City & Guilds Level 3 Certificate in inspection and testing of electrical installations (2391-10).
course.mlo:objective: You will prepare for two examinations, one on-line exam and one practical assessment. Topics covered will be:, Using test instruments and interpreting results. Completing test certificates including inspection and result schedules. Different types of earthing arrangements. Use of human senses. The requirements of EAWR 1989. The relationship between conductor length, cross sectional area (csa), and the effect of temperature on conductor resistance.
course.mlo:prerequisite: It would be expected that candidates have a basic knowledge and understanding of electrical science and principles and experience of electrical installation work either within the electrical contracting industry or allied trades.

course.dc:description:
The BTEC Extended Diploma is a full-time programme, suitable for people who wish to become engineers or technicians within the aeronautical or service community around the world.

It will give you a sound basis to move onto further education at university level or provide employment opportunities that might include eeronautical engineering in any of the armed forces, working as an aircraft technician in the civil aircraft industry or progressing on to become a European Safety Agency licenced aircraft engineer.
course.dc:subject: aeronautical btec level 3 engineering
Engineering
course.dc:title: Aeronautical Engineering EDEXCEL Extended Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Aeronautical Engineering Level 3
course.learningOutcome: On completing this course you will have the skills to go on to university and continue your education to degree level.  You will also have a sound basis should you wish to go into employment as an engineer or technician within the aeronautical or service community around the world.  You may also wish to progress to aeronautical engineering in the armed forces, or to become a European Safety Agency licenced aircraft engineer.
course.mlo:objective:
The BTEC Extended Diploma requires the completion of 16 units of study. The programme comprises four core units;

  • Theory of Flight
  • Principles and Applications of Aircraft Mechanical Science
  • Mathematics for Engineering Technicians
  • Engineering Project

There are also a range of 12 additional units, which may include:

  • Aircraft Propulsion System
  • Airframe Systems
  • Aircraft Materials and Hardware
  • Aircraft Gas Turbine Engines
  • Business Operations in Engineering. 

The course does cover some practical work in airframe repairs and the removal inspection repair and installation of components. Covering in detail many of the systems installed in todays' aircraft, big and small.

The course also looks at legislation, documentation, human factors related to aviation but at the same time many of the individual topics are readily transferrable skills that are recognised by other engineering disciplines.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
You will normally need to have at least one of the following:

  • a BTEC First Certificate or Diploma in a related subject
  • City & Guilds Level 2 Certificate in Aeronautical Engineering
  • an Intermediate GNVQ in a related subject (Merit is desirable)
  • at least four GCSEs at grades A - C including mathematics, English and science.

presentation.dc:subject: Engineering
presentation.dc:title: Aeronautical Engineering EDEXCEL Extended Diploma Level 3

Learners wanting to progress in the building services sector to work with environmental technologies, and qualified and competent practitioners looking to  upskill in the renewables sector via the installation of small scale solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. These systems generate and store electricity from the sun and are designed to help reduce CO² emissions, targeted under the Climate Change Act 2008. 

Learners wanting to progress in the building services sector to work with environmental technologies, and qualified and competent practitioners looking to  upskill in the renewables sector via the installation of small scale solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. These systems generate and store electricity from the sun and are designed to help reduce CO² emissions, targeted under the Climate Change Act 2008.

course.dc:title: Installation and Maintenance of Small Scale Solar Photovoltaic Systems EMTA Award Level 3
course.abstract: Learners wanting to progress in the building services sector to work with environmental technologies
course.learningOutcome: You will enhance your career development and employment opportunities with industry-recognised qualifications.
course.mlo:objective:
The course is structured to facilitate practicing electricians and covers both theoretical and practical applications which are designed to replicate real circumstances. Learners begin by covering The fundamental principles and requirements of environmental technologies are covered first before candidates focus on the installation of small scale solar photovoltaic systems.

The course is  delivered within internal and external workshops. There is also a required element of  independent learning which enables learners to expand on the taught elements of the course.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
• EAL Level 3 award Understanding the fundamental principles and requirements of environmental technology systems + C&G 2356-31 Level 3 NVQ Installation of Electro technical Systems + C&G 2391 Level 3 Inspection & Testing + C&G 2382-10 (full) 17th Edition (BS7671:2008) or C&G 2382-20 (short, 2011 amendment)
OR
• 17th Edition (BS 7671:2008) + Membership of approved bodies, NICEIC; NAPIT or ELECSA
OR
• 17th Edition (BS 7671:2008) + practising domestic installer qualifying, testing and commission of own work.

course.dc:description: This is a part-time course, running one day per week over 15 weeks.  The cost of the course is £675 and there is no fee remission available.  You will be required to purchase your own grooming tunic (approximately £28) and you  may wish to purchase your own grooming kit, although all the equipment is provided within the Grooming Unit.

This College Cerificate course is for those wishing to gain basic skills in dog grooming and bathing, in preparation for the City and Guilds Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists.  It will not give you the qualifications required to work as a professional groomer, but it will give you the experience and skills necessary to progress to Level 3.
course.dc:subject: dog, dog grooming, dog groomer, dogs hair, fur, dog styling
Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Dog Grooming College Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome:
The Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming will give you the knowledge and skills to work as a grooming assistant within the grooming industry.

If you wish to work as a professional dog groomer, you would need to progress onto the nationally- recognised Level 3 Certificate for Introductory Dog Grooming and then the Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists which would require further study at College plus a substantial amount of practical experience in industry to enable you to pass the practical examinations.  The Level 3 Diploma gives you tuition and experience in hand-stripping and also styling and trimming of spaniels, short and long-legged terriers, Schnauzers and poodles to show standards.
course.mlo:objective:
You will have the opportunity to spend time working within the newly designed, well-equipped Dog Grooming Unit at Duchy College Rosewarne.  Here you can practise your skills in bathing and preparing a range of dogs with different coat types for the grooming process and you will also learn some basic trimming techniques.  You will learn the underpinning theory and assessment is via the completion of written assignments and practical assessments. There are no examinations.  The course covers the following units:

  • Approaching dogs, handling, correct control and restraint techniques
  • Health checks and recognising ill-health
  • Preparation and grooming of dogs prior to bathing
  • Correct bathing and cleaning techniques
  • Dry dogs and prepare their coats for styling
  • Basic trimming of a dog’s coat
  • Equipment for grooming – how it is used and maintained
  • Health and safety in the dog grooming environment
  • Dealing with clients
course.mlo:prerequisite: To do this course, you will find it advantageous to be working within the dog grooming industry (either as a volunteer or in paid employment) but this is not essential.  You also need to have a good level of literacy to enable you to complete the assignment work.

presentation.dc:subject: Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
presentation.dc:title: Dog Grooming College Certificate Level 2 (Group 3)

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description: The cost of this one day Taster course is £35.  The course runs from 9.30am until 4.00pm each day and you will need to wear sensible clothing (that you don't mind getting hairy!) and trainers/flat shoes (not flip flops).  You will also need to bring your own lunch, or you can purchase lunch in our cafe at Rosewarne.

This course is ideal if you are interested in finding out more about a career in dog grooming or wanting to learn some basic bathing and grooming techniques for your pet dog.  It will not give you the skills to start up a business as a Dog Groomer but will give you a taster of what this might involve.
course.dc:subject: Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Dog Grooming Taster
course.abstract: Find out more about a career in dog grooming with this Taster course.
course.learningOutcome: Having completed this one day Taster course, you may wish to progress to the Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming (one day per week over 12 weeks).  To gain your professional dog grooming qualifications you will need to progress to the City and Guilds Level 3 Certificate in Introductory Dog Grooming (one day per week over 30 weeks) and the Level 3 Diploma for Professional Dog Stylists.
course.mlo:objective:
This one day (6 hour) course will introduce you to the basics of bathing and grooming dogs in our state-of-the-art Dog Grooming Room at the Animal Management Centre at Duchy College Rosewarne.  It is an excellent starting point for progression to the Level 2 College Certificate in Dog Grooming, after which you can carry on to gain the professional City and Guilds Dog Grooming qualifications at Level 3.

The course covers:

  • Safe working techniques in the grooming salon
  • Approach, handling and restraint of dogs
  • Basic health checks prior to grooming
  • Grooming the coat in preparation for bathing
  • Bathing and cleaning techniques
  • Drying the coat and preparation for styling
  • Grooming equipment and its uses

There are four dates available:  Tuesday 16th June, Tuesday 23rd June, Tuesday 30th June and Tuesday 7th July 2015.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no specific entry requirements, although you will need to be over the age of 16.

presentation.dc:subject: Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
presentation.dc:title: Dog Grooming Taster

This one day course has been developed for dog owners, individuals working in boarding or rehoming kennels, dog walkers/sitters and dog groomers in particular.  

The course costs £100 without funding, but if you are 19+ and working more than eight hours per week in Cornwall, recent European Social  Fund (ESF) funding means that you will only pay £30 per day*. Get in touch to find out more.

Available dates:

  • Saturday 18th April 2015, Rosewarne (Camborne)
  • Saturday 2nd May 2015, Rosewarne (Camborne)
  • Tuesday 12th May 2015, Rosewarne (Camborne)
  • Saturday 23rd May 2015, Rosewarne (Camborne)

course.dc:subject: Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
course.dc:title: Canine First Aid
course.abstract: A 1 day canine first aid course.
course.learningOutcome: Working with animals means that you need to be prepared, and having basic first aid knowledge could save a life.  As well as giving you more confidence in your current job role, having basic first aid skills could also make you more employable in the future.
course.mlo:objective:
The course covers some common first aid problems that you may come across when working with canines, and includes both theory and practical elements. There will be a presentation, a workbook to complete and some practical sessions which will help you to administer basic first aid.

The modules include:

  • Principles of first aid, including legal requirements and limitations

  • The first aid kit, including customizations

  • Approach and assessment of the situation

  • Common emergencies including shock, seizures electrocution, dislocation/fractures and haemorrhage

  • Common problems with geriatric dogs

presentation.dc:subject: Animal Management & Veterinary Nursing
presentation.dc:title: Canine First Aid

The course will be taught as follows, with each day running from 10.00am until 4pm:

  • Day 1 - Wednesday 10th June (Duchy College, Rosewarne)
  • Day 2 - Wednesday 17th June (Duchy College, Rosewarne)
  • Day 3 - Wednesday 1st July (Duchy College, Rosewarne)
  • Day 4 - Wednesday  8th July (Paradise Park, Hayle)

course.learningOutcome: You can take the skills and knowledge learnt on this four day course back to your working environment, and deal more confidently with both domestic and exotic birds.
course.mlo:objective:
This course will cover the following areas:

  • Safe handling, restraint and transportation
  • Temporary accommodation
  • Recognising signs of good and poor health in birds

course.dc:description:
This course is offered at various sites across Cornwall and Devon.

  • Occombe Farm, Paignton, South Devon. The course is centred around sustainable production of a range of food crops where you will cover all aspects of production under cover (Polytunnels), in raised beds and outdoor production.
  • Duchy College,Rosewarne  (Green Fingers) where you will work within the extensive grounds, glasshouses and polytunnels and the Nursery and within the local community.
  • Heaven Scent, Wheel Martyn, St Austell within the Nursery and surrounding grounds.

Ideal if: you would like to improve your horticultural skills and knowledge, whilst gaining a nationally-recognised qualification.

You'll need: at least a GCSE at grade E or above in English and Mathematics, or an equivalent qualification. You will also need to have a keen interest in gardening and the environment.

You'll learn: about propagation, establishing plants, identification of plants, care and maintenance of plants, understanding the growing environment for plants and an introduction to common pests, diseases and their control.

Expect: your assignments and projects to be assessed throughout the course, and of course to get your hands dirty!

You'll love: learning about all aspects of production including polytunnels, raised beds and outdoors.

You'll go onto: a Level 2 Horticulture Apprenticeship or Diploma in which there is the opportunity to specialise in a particular area of horticulture if you so wish.

course.mlo:objective: This course will cover a range of tasks including propagation, establishing plants, identification of plants, care and maintenance of plants, understanding the growing environment for plants and an introduction to common pests, diseases and their control.
course.mlo:prerequisite: A keen interest and enthusiasm in the production of plants and crops. Prepared to get your hands dirty within a range of practical Horticultural situations.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you want to gain the practical skills and knowledge essential for a successful career in environmental conservation.

You’ll need: four GCSEs at grade D or above including English and mathematics, or equivalent qualifications, and a keen interest in conservation.

You’ll learn: a range of skills while working as part of a team surveying and monitoring a range of habitats and working with conservation and environmental groups.

Expect: to produce a portfolio of evidence of all the skills you learn.

You’ll love: working on projects in partnership with leading conservation organisations in Cornwall and Devon.

You’ll go onto: employment in environmental conservation or further study on our Countryside and Wildlife Management Extended Diploma.

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
This is a Level 4 qualification where each module attracts credits towards a City & Guilds Level 4 Diploma in Agricultural Business Management (12 in total).

On the technical side the programme focuses on dairy cows, beef and sheep, the business and finance skills could be applied to any type of farm business.

This flexible programme is designed to fit around your current business activities and work commitments. Each module is delivered in 3 or 4 days. This is supported by considerable study on the farm – putting your theory into practice i.e. application and drawing on the knowledge pool. This approach minimises the impact on your ‘day job’. All modules are delivered by industry and academic experts and supplemented by study materials and online resources for you to use on a day-to-day basis.
course.dc:subject: Agriculture
course.dc:title: Work-Based Agricultural Business Management City & Guilds Diploma Level 4 (QCF)
course.abstract: This programme focuses on dairy cows, beef and sheep, the business and finance skills could be applied to any farm business.
course.mlo:assessment: Assessments are predominantly farm based and will focus on knowledge/understanding, appraisal, planning for improvement, implementation, monitoring and evaluation. Thus students apply what they have studied to their own situation.
course.learningOutcome: You could go on to study our FdSc Agriculture (Level 5) or seek employment progression as a result of successful completion.
course.mlo:objective:
Our innovative and flexible approach aims to minimise the time spent away from your job – so you can apply your learning back in the workplace immediately.

It is planned that all of the above modules would be offered to participants over a 24 month period with a further 6 months required for the completion of assessment.

The programme will commence In September 2015 and run for 20 to 25 days over two winters. Attendance will be one day per week, running until Easter time.

Assessment will be mainly farm based and ongoing throughout the two years. A specialist assessor will visit the farm on a regular basis to collect evidence. This will comprise farm documentation (hard or on screen), professional discussion, written supporting and explanatory evidence, observation and witness/personal statements. There are no examinations or written tests in the Diploma.

The programme will run from Stoke Climsland and subject to numbers also from Rosewarne

Standard training days will be 9.30am to 4.30pm.

Delivery will be very much along the lines of a discussion group led much of the time by a specialist speaker from Industry.

Note for those doing the Apprenticeships there will be a need to do some additional qualifications including Functional Skills at Level 2 in Literacy and Numeracy (unless these have already been achieved).
course.mlo:prerequisite:
The course is aimed at those:

  • Who have achieved a Level 3 Diploma / Extended Diploma in Agriculture (formerly the National Certificate / Diploma) or a Level 3 Work-based Diploma in Agriculture (formerly NVQ Level 3), or similar, and are now working in the agricultural industry and aiming to take on more responsibility, or those that need to develop higher level skills in post.
  • Individuals who have obtained a HND or degree will benefit considerably from the applied nature of this programme and are eligible for entry.

For those without the qualifications above please contact us to discuss your eligibility.

course.dc:description: The level 3 training will enable you to run a Forest school in partnership with local schools and pre schools, delivering an alternative complimentary curriculum to Foundation Stage, Primary or Secondary school children. You may also offer Family Fun Forest School events or similar.
This course is designed to meet the needs of Teachers, Teaching Assistants, Early Years Educators, Youth Workers, Play Workers and other professionals in training as a Forest School Leader.
course.dc:subject: Early Years, Playwork & Forest School
course.dc:title: Forest School Programme Leadership AptEd Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: The training is suitable for teachers, play workers, early years professionals, early years workers, forest school childcare early duchy
course.learningOutcome: Successful candidates can seek employment within the children's workforce as a Forest School Leader or become a self-employed provider of Forest School.
course.mlo:objective:
This course enables learners to gain the skills and knowledge required to plan and lead groups in Forest School Programmes and activities.  The course consists of taught theory and practical elements as well as coursework to be completed during and after initial training. You will complete 5 units linked to learning outcomes:

  • Delivery of Forest School - this includes planning, leading and evaluating a pilot programme of a minimum of 6 sessions with your client group.
  • Forest School Practical Skills
  • Forest School and the Woodland Environment
  • Learning and Development at Forest School
  • Planning Forest School

Duration: one day every other week for 8 weeks (no session during school half term) plus around 110 hours of self-study supported by extensive resources in our virtual learning environment. In person, email and telephone tutorial support is available by arrangement with the course tutor. All enrolled students have access to the learning resource centres on all Cornwall College campuses for one year. Learners are expected to submit completed portfolios of work 10 months from the date of enrolment.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
• Age 21 years or over
  • Have a level 3 or above qualification ( NNEB, Teacher, Play worker or Youth worker (to level 3 or equivalent) OR level 2 with a portfolio of at least 2 years experience of working with children/young people in a leadership capacity
  • Have considerable experience of working with young people
  • Before leading sessions, learners must ensure that they have a valid DBS check, first aid provision and appropriate insurance and site permissions.
  • By the end of the course you will need to complete a 2 day certificated course in Outdoor First Aid for the Forest School practitioner.  Details of trainers in the area can be provided.

The Certificate in Food Manufacturing Excellence is for those wishing to undertake a sustainable continuous improvement programme delivered entirely in the workplace, alongside appreciating the principles of working in food manufacture.  A practical combination of hygiene and food safety regulations, together with the application of continuous improvement techniques delivers many business benefits.
course.dc:subject: Food manufacturing, catering, food, food and drink, food and drink manufacturing, operations, food & drink, manufacturing, NVQ, proficiency in food, manufacturing excellence, fdq
Food Manufacturing & Technology
course.dc:title: Food Manufacturing Excellence FDQ Certificate for Proficiency Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion, learners may choose to progress to the next Level.
course.mlo:objective:
During this course, you will develop and demonstrate competence in a range of practical areas, which principally include:

  • Working together as a team
  • Product quality
  • Food safety
  • Health and safety
  • Resolution of problems through diagnosis
  • Continuous improvement
  • Development of standard operating procedures
  • HACCP
  • Waste identification
  • Risk management

These qualifications offer a mix of competence to suit the needs of the industry.  Essentially they contain a blend of change management, improvement tools and techniques and other supporting competences which endeavour to provide sustainability for lean culture and its application within the sector. 

This course is studied entirely in your work-place developing and adding knowledge and proficiency to your normal job of work. Assessments are through observations, discussions, questioning sessions and through the construction of a portfolio of evidence.

The duration of this programme is dependent on the business needs, but the average timescale is 12-16 weeks, with eight 1 day workshops included.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, but you must be employed within the food industry.  It is also expected that a genuine interest is held in supporting discussions with our team of experts to ensure that the principles are being implemented and that change is happening.

The Certificate in Food Manufacturing Excellence is for those wishing to undertake an intermediate sustainable continuous improvement programme delivered entirely in the workplace, alongside appreciating the principles of working in food manufacture.  A practical combination of hygiene and food safety regulations, together with the application of continuous improvement techniques delivers many business benefits.
course.dc:subject: food manufacturing, food proficiency, lean, six signma, FDQ, Food, Certificate for Proficiency
Food Manufacturing & Technology
course.dc:title: Food Manufacturing Excellence FDQ Certificate for Proficiency Level 3
course.learningOutcome: Upon successful completion, learners may choose to progress to the next Level.
course.mlo:objective:
During this course, you will complete 27 credits, which are made up from units drawn from 3 groups:

  • Change Management - these units enable learners to develop the competencies to engage and develop people during the change process
  • Tools and Techniques – the tools and techniques necessary to drive improvement in a food environment, including Kaizen and Six Sigma
  • Food Manufacturing Knowledge - these units underpin the tools and techniques.

The aims and objectives for this course are:

  • Sustainable development & performance improvement
  • Re-establish the basics
  • Establish competence and credibility for First Line Managers
  • Develop assessment skills to ensure learning is implemented
  • Engage all levels in the business in a problem solving culture
  • Establish a performance improvement culture
  • Reinforce key behaviours
  • Develop competence in Lean Management Tools & Techniques
  • Be a key part of your business’ future profitability.

Assessment is through means of observations, discussions, questioning sessions and through the construction of a portfolio of evidence.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, but you must be employed within the food industry. A Level 2 Certificate is desirable, while it is expected that a genuine interest is held in supporting discussions with our team of experts to ensure that the principles are being implemented and that change is happening.

course.dc:description: If you have a passion for food or science, or care about how your food is produced then the Level 3 Diploma in food Technology and Management is for you!  Food technology combines many aspects including a range of sciences, practical food production, design and technology so the course is challenging and stimulating.
course.dc:subject: food food technology meat dairy bakery processing science microbiology
Food Manufacturing & Technology
course.dc:title: Food Technology and Management FDQ Diploma Level 3
course.abstract: Have a passion for food or science, or care about how your food is produced?
course.learningOutcome:
Having completed the Diploma, you could start your career in the country's largest industry, working in dairy, meat, fish, bakery, fruit and vegetable or even the confectionery or beverage sectors.  You could chose to work in a laboratory or as a technical technologist or you might prefer to work in the production of foods.  The course aims to enable you to work at supervisor level although most companies will want you to undertake an induction before taking command of a production line.

Students who want to go on to higher education can continue their studies at Duchy College, by going on to the two year FdSc Food Studies and may, on successful completion, continue onto the final year of a relevant honours degree at the College.
course.mlo:objective:
During year one of the course you will study the production of a wide range of products including fruit and vegetable products, dairy products (cheese, cream, butter, yogurt and so on) and bakery products.  You will also study how to produce these foods safely, which will include microbiology and food safety issues.  Since we aim to be able to sell some of our produce you will learn about food labelling and packaging.  In year one you will also study the underpinning science behind food manufacturing.

In the second year of the course you will get the opportunity to learn about the production of meat and fish products which will give you a breadth of knowledge across the wider food sector.  You will also learn how to develop new products and will undertake a project linked to this, which may well be driven by one of our partner businesses.  During this second year you will learn some of the key management techniques so that you should be able to work at supervisor level and may work with year one students to supervise their work.

Throughout the course you will produce foods in our fantastic, registered food processing unit, where you will learn the importance of working to food industry standards.  You will also have the chance to visit a wide range of local food businesses to see how what you are learning is put into practise commercially.  Our friendly team of staff will help you develop your study skills so that you can achieve a high level if you choose.  This will also enable you to progress onto the Foundation Degree in Food Studies offered here at Duchy College.
course.mlo:prerequisite: To gain entry to the course you should have a suitable level 2 qualification.  These include, 4 GCSE at grade A-C or a level 2 NVQ.

This qualification is specifically designed for practising or aspiring managers on Senior Apprenticeship/Development programmes. It contains a comprehensive range of management  topics, tailored for first line managers and those moving into a management role.
course.dc:subject: Principles Leadership Management ILM Certificate Level 3
Business, Administration & Law
course.dc:title: Principles of Leadership and Management ILM Certificate Level 3
course.learningOutcome:
This qualification will provide progression opportunities to a range of management subjects such as:

  • L3 Certificate in Leadership
  • L3 Certificate in Effective Management
  • L3 Certificates in Coaching and/or Mentoring
  • L4 Award in Leadership & Management
course.mlo:objective:
The course is held over 8 days and the workshops will involve group discussions, exercises, case studies and project work.

The programme will look to develop a full range of management skills including:

  • Day 1 - Introduction to leadership
  • Day 2 - Solving problems and making decisions
  • Day 3 - Leading a Team Effectively
  • Day 4 & 5 - Change Management
  • Day 6 to 8 - Management specialist subjects

Assessment is by completion of Reflective Reviews and project based assignments. Successful completion will lead to a nationally recognised Level 3 management qualification.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements, but participants will normally be either practising or aspiring first line managers on a  Senior Apprenticeship/Development programme.

course.dc:description:
Ideal if: you are interested in working in countryside conservation, wildlife management, forestry, estates or river management.

You'll need: four GCSEs at grade D or above including English and mathematics, or equivalent qualifications, and a keen interest in the countryside.

You'll learn: conservation and wildlife habitat management at college and gain a variety of experience and skills including practical work on local sites and woodlands. You'll also learn valuable theory in subjects such as habitat management, estate maintenance, and livestock conservation management.

Expect: to undertake a work placementwithin the rural sector to build confidence, become adaptable in the work place and develop transferable skills.

You'll love: regularly conducting conservation work with Cornwall Wildlife Trust and Duchy Woodlands as well as our strong links with Cornwall County Council, The National Trust and RSPB.

You'll go onto: further study such as the BTEC Extended Diploma in Countryside Management. There are future job opportunities as Ranger, Woodland Manager, or Conservation Officer.
course.dc:subject: game management, game birds, shoot, shoots, shooting, animal care, animal management, breeding, culling, estate management, estate managing, wildlife, warden, gamekeeping, gamekeeper, game keeping, game keeper, apprentice, apprenticeship, apprenticeships,
Apprenticeships

course.abstract: A work-based qualification for those passionate about the countryside.
course.learningOutcome: If you have really enjoyed this course, you could progress to the BTEC Extended Diploma in Countryside Management. Alternatively, you could consider employment opportunities as a Ranger, Woodland Manager or Conservation Officer.
course.mlo:objective: This Level 2 work-based Diploma will provide you with essential skills needed to work on the land in many different areas. You will undertake practical work on local sites and woodlands, learn about safe working practices as well as the theory behind habitate management, estate maintenance and livestock conservation management.
course.mlo:prerequisite: You will need to have four GCSEs at Grade D or above including English and Maths or the equivalent, with a good standard of secondary education and a keen interest in the countryside.

course.dc:description:
The purpose of this level 1 qualification in practical horticultural skills is to provide learners, industry and other stakeholders with the fundamental skills required in horticulture. It is a flexible system with a wide range of units in discrete horticultural skills, that can be built up into a full qualification or accessed as individual units, and, as such, it meets the needs of learners from a wide range of abilities and backgrounds.
The units cover a wide range of horticultural tasks and give great flexibility to the qualification. It is particularly suitable for entrants into all sectors of horticulture, including those who need to work up from lower levels and is suitable for anyone who requires training in fundamental practical horticulture skills. It has proved to be useful for entry into horticulture, leading on to higher qualifications.

course.dc:description: Anyone aged between 16 and 19 years of age who wants to improve and develop their skills before progressing to either a level one course or the workplace.
course.dc:title: Vocational Tasters/Options
course.learningOutcome: You can either go into employment or progress to a level one course. Those who achieve elements of the course at Level 1 may be able to progress to a Level 2 course.
course.mlo:objective: You will study Literacy, Numeracy and Information and Communication Technology. You will develop your ability to work as part of a team and independently. There will be time to improve on your communication and work skills, build your confidence and prepare yourself for the next step onto either employment or a level one qualification. You will also have the opportunity to try out various vocational options, or study units of a vocational subject that interests you.
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal entry requirements. You will be asked to attend an interview with the Course Manager before starting the course and you will be encouraged to attend a taster. You can start in September, January or April. Be prepared to take part in work experience as well as college based learning.

course.dc:description:
The course will cost £900 which will include access to:-

The student site of the College of Policing ‘Pre Join Domain,’ – which includes the following resources for up to 3 years.

All Pre-join related e-learning (approximately 30 short courses)
Fully maintained electronic version of the IPLDP QuickNotes
Fully maintained versions of Student Notes for all modules of the Pre-Join Curriculum
Fully maintained audio versions (in MP3 format) of Student Notes for all modules of the Pre-Join Curriculum.

Achievement of the Certificate in Knowledge in Policing (CKP) will help prepare those seeking recruitment to the Police Service as a Police Constable in England or Wales. The qualification is also relevant to other related roles within the Criminal Justice Sector.

The certificate is an important element of the Professional Entry into Policing Pre-Join Strategy, and accredits the knowledge and understanding which also forms part of the Diploma in Policing qualification. The Diploma in Policing is the minimum mandatory qualification which Regular Police Constables are required to achieve to be confirmed in rank and forms part of the Initial Police Learning and Development Programme (IPLDP). All those who achieve the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing through a provider approved by the College of Policing will be able to submit this as evidence of the knowledge component of the Diploma. All awarding organisations offering the Diploma in Policing recognise and accept the relationship between the CKP and Diploma in Policing.

Successful achievement of the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing does not in itself provide any guarantee of recruitment as a trainee Police Constable. Each police force within England and Wales sets out its own recruitment process and selection policy and entry requirements vary from force to force. Prospective students are therefore strongly advised to check the specific requirements of their chosen force prior to undertaking study.

It should be noted that all candidates need to pass medical and fitness tests as well as background and security checks and undertake a series of assessments, tests and an interview at a Police SEARCH® assessment centre.

The CKP will be delivered through a number of guided learning sessions and some directed study.  The students will be expected to study in their own time between sessions in order to successfully complete the course.
course.dc:subject: Police; Policing; Knowledge Certificate in Policing; Police pre-join certificate, specials, law enforcing, constable
Public Services
course.dc:title: Certificate in Knowledge of Policing City & Guilds (3945-30/93) Certificate Level 3
course.abstract: Certificate in Knowledge of Policing
course.learningOutcome:
There are no guarantees of employment following completion of this course. Although you may still be eligible to join the police service if you have minor convictions/cautions, there are certain offences and conditions that will make you ineligible. If you are at all unsure, contact your chosen force for more information.

The Certificate will remain valid for a period of 4 years for those who have continuing operational experience in policing (operational Special Constables and PCSOs).

For students undertaking a Foundation Degree in Policing and those who undertake the Certificate in Knowledge of Policing as a stand-alone course the currency of the certificate will be three years from completion of the Foundation degree or the stand-alone course.
course.mlo:objective: The Certificate in Knowledge of Policing course is one of a range of qualifications which can be accepted as evidence of Recognised (Accredited) Prior Learning (RPL) towards the Diploma in Policing but only represents circa 50% of the Diploma. It comprises some elements of the Initial Police Learning and Development Programme (IPLDP), which is the required learning programme undertaken by all trainee Regular Police Constables to the Police Service of England and Wales. The course is delivered through 10 individual units on a part-time basis, part of the course is taught, and the remainder of study is carried out on a self-study basis.  Assessment will be through a series of in-class tests.
course.mlo:prerequisite: Candidates should be a minimum of 19 years of age and capable of undertaking a Level 3 programme of study.

presentation.dc:subject: Public Services

course.dc:description:
Students will be required to purchase the following items of personal uniform from the suggested supplier or from a supplier of their choice to wear on the course. 

 Cadet Uniform package cost £40 inc VAT consisting of: Assault boots, Soldier 95 trousers, shirt and Ripstop jacket, 2 piece cameo wet weather suit and commando socks. Available from:http://www.britishmilitarysurplus.co.uk/ishop/1069/shopscr43.html

 In addition, a tracksuit and T shirt embroidered with the College Military Academy logo is required and can be purchased from: http://www.plymouthmilitarygifts.com/store/Duchy_College.html Embroidered Track Suit £32.99, embroidered T shirts £4.50.

 Large or expensive items of kit such as Bergens, cooking equipment, tents, sleeping bags etc will be provided by the College.  Students are encouraged to purchase/bring their own sleeping bags etc if they prefer. A refundable deposit of £35 is required for the issue of College kit and equipment.

 There is an additional cost of £55 for the 3 day survival school training course which is delivered by an outside provider and £20 for issue of rations for overnight exerccises.

 

Financial support may be available from the student support fund, details are available from Student Services.

The NCFE Level 2 Diploma for Entry to the Uniformed Services is part of the Cornwall College Military Academy and is designed to prepare potential recruits for entry to the Armed Forces.  The course is 16 weeks and runs from January. The programme is portfolio based therefore there are no examinations. All theory and practical assessment will be conducted in the class room or out-doors as suitable. Learners will undertake practical military training and education in order to equip them with the necessary skills to enable them to make decisions on which service to apply for and to prepare them in all respects for initial selection. Alongside the main qualification learners will undertake GCSE or functional skills in English and/or maths dependant on their entry qualifications.
course.dc:subject: Public Services
course.dc:title: Entry to the Uniformed Services NCFE Diploma Level 2
course.abstract: This intensive 16 week course will prepare you for entry to the Armed Forces. Courses run September-January and February-June.
course.mlo:assessment:
There are no examinations in this course, assessment is through a portfolio based system. Students are issued with a complete portfolio of their programme which gives full information of the learning outcomes for each individual unit of study. After each practical activity or lesson students write up reflective logs to record what they have learnt and answer specific questions associated with the learning outcomes for that unit. To pass the course a student must provide evidence in their portfolio that they have completed 100% of the learning outcomes and assessment for each unit. Units are graded pass, merit or distinction and students receive an overall grade for completing their course.

The main evidencefor the portfolio may include:

  • candidates proof of work
  • Assessor observation
  • witness testimony
  • worksheets
  • assignments, projects or reports
  • records of professional discussion
  • record of oral and written questioning
  • candidate and peer reports
  • recognition of prior learning (RPL)
course.learningOutcome:
On successful completion of your course you can apply for selection to the Armed Service of your choice. 

Or you can progress to :

  • Entry to the Uniformed Services NCFE Diploma (Military Academy) Level 3
  • Public Services (Uniformed) BTEC Extended Diploma Level 3 (5 x GCSE grade C including English and/or maths are required for this course).
course.mlo:objective:
The aim of this course is to prepare you for Armed Forces selection. You will study a number of units which will improve your overall fitness and stamina levels and equip you with the knowledge and skills to allow you to perform to the best of your ability at the Armed Forces selection centre. 

Units include:

  • Investigate employment in the uniformed services
  • Physical fitness for the uniformed services
  • Develop team working and problem-solving skills
  • Health and safety in the uniformed services
  • Health and hygiene in the uniformed services
  • Carry out map reading and navigation
  • Follow uniformed services routine
  • Exploring equality and diversity for the uniformed services
  • Participate in competitive sports
course.mlo:prerequisite: There are no formal academic entry requirements for this course. However, learners will be expected to be able to work towards GCSE or functional skills in English and/or maths dependant on individual entry qualifications.

This outstanding programme is designed to make learners employable at the end of the course and ready for a career in the outdoor industry.
It is designed for those learners wanting to gain valuable practical experience in instructor training alongside gaining the relevant industry National Governing Body awards to improve personal skills and practical ability in a variety of outdoor and adventurous activites.
course.dc:subject: outdoor instructor kayak canoe climbing pursuits sport
Outdoor Pursuits & Adventurous Activity
course.dc:title: Outdoor Instructor Training Programme
course.abstract: Designed for those wanting to gain practical experience in instructor training
course.learningOutcome:
• Progress onto the Advanced Instructor Training Programme Level 3
  • Gain employment in the outdoor industry
course.mlo:objective:
• The college week consists of 1 day theory work and 2-3 full days of practical activity covering land and water-based instructor training throughout the course. Attendance for these days, whatever the weather, is compulsory to be successful to gain a well-rounded understanding of the role of an instructor in a work setting; you will be continuously assessed and gather evidence for your final portfolio.
  • Develop leadership skills to safely lead safe, effective and enjoyable land and water-based sessions for school groups. 
  • Undertake a summer season placement at an outdoor centre.
  • You will have opportunity to gain a range of outdoor / leadership qualifications, e.g. Paddlesports 1* & 2*, BCU Level 1 Coach, CWA training, Mountain Bike Leaders, and First Aid for the Outdoors.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
There are no formal entry requirements However, all learners will demonstrate an outstanding work ethic and motivation throughout the course to progress to the work placement after Easter of the course. 

All learners are required to be water confident and able to swim 50 meters in open water.
Relevant Senior Tutor and employer DBS checks will be undertaken to ensure that all learners are suitable to be working with young children and vulnerable adults; two successful character references will also be required.

Finally, in order to successfully undertake the outdoor provider work placement you will be required to be 18 years old by the end of the course.

course.dc:description: This two-day course provides the skills required when acting as an escort craft, safety boat or coach boat for a fleet of dinghies, windsurfers or canoes, or for racing or training activities.

Leisure & Watersports
course.dc:title: Safety Boat RYA Certificate Level 2
course.learningOutcome: Successful completion of this course will widen your future career prospects and employment opportunities. You will now be able to provide safety cover to a range of craft.
course.mlo:objective: This RYA qualification offers study and practical training in boat handling, towing, fleet management, rescue techniques for sailing dinghies, windsurfers and canoes.
course.mlo:prerequisite: For entry on this course, you will need an RYA Powerboat Level 2 Certificate and a basic understanding of sailing boats and windsurfers.

presentation.dc:subject: Leisure & Watersports
presentation.dc:title: Safety Boat RYA Certificate Level 2

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Regarded by many as the 'driving licence' for powerboats, our RYA Powerboat Level 2 course offers a thorough introduction to powerboat handling.

Topics covered include:

  • Launching and recovery
  • Confined space manoeuvring
  • Mooring
  • Man over board procedure
  • Anchoring
  • Towing
  • Engine checks
  • High speed handling
  • Collision regulations
  • Buoyage
  • Basic chartwork and navigation
  • Tides
  • Communication afloat
  • Emergency procedures

Your level 2 certificate can also be exchanged for the International Certificate of Competence (ICC) for vessels up to 10 m / 33ft. We also offer the CEVNI (European inland waterways theory) test FREE of charge to anyone taking a practical course with us. The ICC is only available to people aged 16 years+ who are either British Residents or British Passport holders.
course.dc:subject: powerboat, power boats, RYA, watersports, outdoor pursuits, outdoors sports, water sports, watersports, sailing, boat, boats, boating, instructor, coaching,
course.dc:title: National Powerboat RYA Certificate Level 2
course.mlo:objective:
RYA Powerboat Level 2

This two-day course provides the skills and background knowledge needed to drive a powerboat and is the basis of the International Certificate of Competence.

It includes close quarters handling, high speed manoeuvres, man overboard recovery and collision regulations. The course can be taken inland or on the coast and your certificate will be endorsed accordingly.
course.mlo:prerequisite: None (it is not necessary to have completed the level 1 course)

presentation.dc:title: Powerboat RYA Certificate Level 2

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Start windsurfing instructor training 

RYA Start Windsurfing instructors are qualified to teach the Start Windsurfing course and Stages 1 and 2 of the Youth Windsurfing Scheme under the supervision of a senior instructor. In addition the instructor certificate is endorsed to show whether you are qualified to teach on inland or coastal waters. The instructor is a competent, experienced windsurfer capable of windsurfing in strong winds and handling small powerboats. The instructor has been assessed as competent to teach adults and children at the beginner level. Although responsible for teaching individuals and small groups, the instructor has not been assessed as competent in running a sailing centre, and should always work under the supervision of an RYA Senior instructor (for dinghy and multihull courses) or the chief instructor of a keelboat training centre.
course.dc:subject: RYA, surfing, kayaking, watersports, marine, outdoor, instructor, instructer, coach, RYA, BCU, Extreme, adventure, sports, water, sports, wind, coaching, instructing,
Leisure & Watersports
course.dc:title: Windsurfing Assistant Instructor RYA Level 1
course.learningOutcome: You will be qualified to work within the watersports industry as a windsurf coach or you might wish to undertake one of our full time instructor training courses to qualify with Sailing, kayaking and powerboating.
course.mlo:objective:
This course runs over a 5 day period with the final day being the moderation and assessment of candidates (this aspect is run by an external examiner). 

 Expect the course to run into the evenings on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The course will begin at 9.00am each day.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
• Minimum age 16;
  • Intermediate non-planing certificate with beach starting and non-planing gybe clinics;
  • RYA Powerboat level 2 certificate;
  • Valid first aid qualification. *
  • Course duration
  • The course will be run over five days.

presentation.dc:subject: Leisure & Watersports
presentation.dc:title: Windsurfing Assistant Instructor RYA Level 1

CE:cost.dc:description: Please call our Enquiries Team for more details on this course.

course.dc:description:
Duration: 5days

 Dates: Please contact main reception on 01326 310310

Training in teaching techniques afloat and ashore is provided during the instructor training course, which is staffed by RYA Coach/Assessors. The course will be based on a five-day week or 50 hours. Courses run on a protracted basis may take slightly longer than 50 hours to allow for revision time.

Instructor certificates are valid for three years from the date of issue, provided that a valid first aid certificate is maintained.
course.dc:subject: rya, watersports, water, sports, dingy, instructor, coach, sailing,
Leisure & Watersports
course.dc:title: Dinghy Instructor RYA Level 2
course.learningOutcome: When qualified as an instructor you will be eligible to work for outdoor centres both in the UK and worldwide. You will be qualified to teach beginners in all aspects of the sport.
course.mlo:objective:
Dinghy, keelboat & multihull instructor training 

Instructors teaching the National Sailing Scheme need to be qualified for the type of boat in which they teach, ie dinghies, small keelboats or multihulls. In addition the instructor certificate is endorsed to show whether you are qualified to teach on inland or coastal waters. The instructor is a competent, experienced sailor capable of sailing a training boat in strong winds and handling small powerboats. The instructor has been assessed as competent to teach adults and children, beginners and improvers. Although responsible for teaching individuals and small groups, the instructor has not been assessed as competent in running a sailing centre, and should always work under the supervision of an RYA Senior instructor (for dinghy and multihull courses) or the chief instructor of a keelboat training centre.
course.mlo:prerequisite:
Minimum age 16, valid first aid qualification. Acceptable certificates include the RYA’s First Aid Certificate, First Aid at Work, First Aid at Sea, or any other certificate issued on completion of a course which is a minimum of one day’s duration, recognised by the Health and Safety Executive and includes the treatment of hypothermia, cold shock and drowning. 

You must also be a member of the national governing body (Royal Yachting Association for windsurfing/dinghy sailing and the British Canoe Union for Paddlesport).

Pre requisites:

RYA Powerboat Level 2

RYA intermediate sailing

RYA Day sailing

RYA Pre instructor assessment

course.dc:description: These courses are ongoing, please contact reception on 01326 310310 for availability

Instructor training courses

Training in teaching techniques afloat and ashore is provided during the instructor training course, which is staffed by RYA Coach/Assessors. The course will be based on a five-day week or 50 hours. Courses run on a protracted basis may take slightly longer than 50 hours to allow for revision time.

Instructor certificates are valid for three years from the date of issue, provided that a valid first aid certificate is maintained.
